Ottawa, June 27, 1944.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
538 Dominion Public Building, Winnipeg, Man.

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, with reference to the report of the Fire Inspector regarding the Elkhorn School.

You may authorize the changing of the windows to doors in those places where such changes are necessary.

I agree with you that locks are not necessary.

You should also direct the Principal's attention to the other recommendations that the Department wishes. These recommendations to be put into effect immediately.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Repair Work at Elkhorn School

The electric pump used to pump out the sewerage tank at Elkhorn Indian School is reported worn out and past repairing. I understand the pump has been in use for many years. Before any purchase is made I would suggest that Mr. Yates, of Yates and Nield, Plumbers, Brandon, be employed to inspect conditions and submit definite recommendations as to the type of pump required.

I would also point out that sixty of the bedsprings are in a disgraceful condition and unfit for further use. The Parkhill Bedding Company will undertake to do the repair work, but as the springs are of different sizes they are unable to give a quotation. However, the beds must be repaired and I would be glad to have the necessary authority to proceed with the work at once.

The stairway to the basement on both the boys' and the girls' side of the building needs extensive repairs. I have asked the acting Principal to secure a price on the work and this estimate will be forwarded when received.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

RE: SEWERAGE PUMP
ELKHORN, Manitoba.

We have inspected the Sewerage Pump and Installation and report as follows:

The Pump is a Vertical Centrifugal Pump set in a Concrete Well. The Well is five feet nine inches square. Nineteen feet deep. The concrete top, bottom and sides are in good condition. There are four by four beams in the centre to carry the Pump Shaft. These are in good condition but where the holes are drilled for the bearings the holes are worn big. The Sewerage is admitted into the tank at a depth of ten feet five inches from the top of the tank.

The sewerage enters the tank after going through the Septic Tank and is clear water without any solids. The Water is elevated Twenty Five feet into a trough which conveys the water away from the buildings.

The Pump Shaft is twenty feet long anchored in three places down the well. These bearings are worn, the first has one and one half inches of play, the second has two inches of play and the third is broken entirely. The shaft moves approximately three inches from side to side while running.

The pump is of unknown manufacture. We could not empty all the water out of the tank because the pump would not lift the last two feet out of the well. This is an indication that the Impeller Blades are badly worn giving too much room between them and the pump housing. The head of the pump is badly worn there being about an inch of play where the shaft enters the pump. This was shimmed up by the School Engineer in June who wedged a piece of steel between the shaft and the pump head. This has cut down some of the play.

We would recommend that the following be done:

The Pump being of unknown manufacture the Impeller Blades are worn and the head also worn. We would recommend that a new pump of similar design.

A new shaft should be installed with three new shaft bearings.

The Braces: Four inch Angle Iron should be bolted to the present four by four's with the shaft bearings bolted to the steel.

The four inch discharge pipe will have to be renewed.

The line shaft could be done away with by installing a support-motor and stand on top of the shaft.

We have written for prices on another pump of a similar design and will quote you a price when we have the necessary information.

We remain,

Yours very truly,

"R.A. Yates"

Yates & Company

Dear Sir:

Re: Sewerage Pump,
Elkhorn, Manitoba.

We are very pleased to quote you on supplying and installing a Sewerage Pump in the Elkhorn School. The Pump will be:

2" Fairbanks Morse Fig 541OW Vertical submerged base mounted Sewerage and Trash Pump for use with type "T" enclosed shaft drive, built-in frame #1 enclosed shaft drive, built-in frame #1 having maximum 7" diameter impeller #T2ALA capable of passing solids up to 1½" spheres, designed for mounting on floor pit and held by foundation bolts with:

Belted mounted head and vertical pulley 7½" diameter x 10" face, for ¼ twist flat belt drive, with #6 hand operated oiler complete with bracket and fittings to top bearings, tube tension nut, oil cap with bolts and nuts to take shaft enclosing tube.

16'5" approximately 1½ precision steel shaft with 2" enclosing shaft tube of extra strong pipe with connecting bearings and intermediate bearings, placed approximately 4' apart, so as to make the distance from the bottom mounting head 19'.

To install this pump complete, renew the discharge pipe for the sum of:

SEVEN HUNDRED AND FORTY DOLLARS --------------($740.00)

The very best delivery we can promise under present conditions is about Four Months from receipt of the order if accompanied with a priority of AA-4 or higher.

Yours very truly,

"R.A.Yates"

Yates & Company.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

The roof of the school is, I understand, covered with tin or some such metal. It leaks in various places and should be repaired. It might be advisable to have this examined by someone from the Surveys and Engineering Branch, Dominion Water and Power Bureau, Winnipeg, of which Mr. Gow is in charge and a recommendation obtained. Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

I have your letter of the 7th instant, reporting on your visit to the Elkhorn Residential School on October 31 and November 1. The following expenditures are approved:

1. Repairs to plumbing and installing of extra tubs and toilet bowls - $550.
2. Repairs to stairs - material and labour - $401.65.
3. Purchase of 24 unpainted kitchen chairs and 2 heavy work tables for the kitchen.

We have already placed the order for the pump for the septic tank and copy of purchase order 27529 was forwarded to you on the 8th instant. The Purchasing Branch is being requested to secure the mattresses and paint.

I trust that you will be able to have the work authorized in this letter completed at the earliest possible date.

With reference to the expenditure of $2000 which you estimate will be the cost of reflooring the halls and dormitories, I am not certain at the present time if we can provide the funds from the current year's appropriation. Is it possible to secure the lumber that would be required for this work at the present time? If
so, you might let me know the exact type of lumber which is necessary and the name of the firm from whom you consider it could be secured. When we have this information the matter will have further consideration.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
MEMORANDUM.

RE: ELKHORN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, ELKHORN, MANITOBA.

Further to our memorandum dated the 18th ultimo regarding an inspection of the roof of the above school, you are advised that a report has been received from Mr. Gow which is summarized as follows:

Mr. Gow was accompanied on his inspection by Mr. Zeigler, Manager of the Central Sheet Metal Works of Brandon, Manitoba. He reports that the school was erected in 1897 and enlarged at a later date. The original building has a mansard roof, on which both the flat deck and sloping surfaces are metal covered. Leakages occur intermittently through the ceilings of three rooms located in the newer portion of the building, the roof of which is flat and also metal covered.

After his examination of the roof surfaces, Mr. Gow reports that one leak occurs where a plumbing vent passes through the covering, but that the sources of the other two leaks may be some distance from the points where water enters the rooms.

Mr. Gow reports that there is very little evidence of repairs of any extent having been carried out, and that the metal roof covering now in place may be the original installation. There are a few small breaks and holes in the metal covering and, while the metal has deteriorated, such deterioration seems to be uniform.

It is reported that several sections of the metal roof covering have become detached from the roof deck, due to the battens holding the metal in place having become loosened. Mr. Gow states that the roof covering will, eventually, have to be replaced, but for the present it is serviceable. He considers the existing leaks can be eliminated by minor repairs.

Mr. Gow also inspected the class room building at the school, situated about 250 yards distant from the main building. He reports it to be a two-storey frame structure which originally occupied another site. It is understood that this building was moved to its present position after a new foundation had been built for it. The lower floor contains three class rooms and storage space, while the upper floor is unfinished and is not being used. This building also has a mansard roof.

J.M.Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.
the flat deck of which is covered with ready roofing and the sloping surfaces a shingle finish. Mr. Gow reports that leakages are occurring through the ready roofing but that the shingles appear to be in fair condition. Temporary repairs to the ready roofing are suggested by Mr. Gow.

It is considered evident from the report that the class room building suffered considerable damage while being moved. The report indicates that the superstructure is resting unevenly on the foundation, which has caused warping of the frame walls, with the result that windows have become distorted and displacement of structural members framing the mansard roof has occurred. In this connection, the following excerpt from Mr. Gow's report is quoted:

"A thorough examination is necessary by a competent carpenter to determine just what is involved in making this building structurally safe and repairing the second storey windows. The present roof on this building will shortly have to be replaced with a more substantial covering than the present tar paper. The shingles of the mansard roofing appear to be in fair condition."

The Elkhorn Indian School is an old building and considerable replacement work will be necessary, both within and on the outside of the buildings if the school is to continue operating. I understand that the matter of continuing the operation of this school is receiving consideration and accordingly only such minor repairs as are urgent should be proceeded with. We are not prepared to make any estimate of the probable cost of repairs to the class room building."

Mr. Gow reports having discussed the matter of immediately necessary repairs with Mr. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies at Winnipeg, and with the Principal and Engineer at the school. It was agreed that roof repairs of a temporary character were to be carried out by the school engineer and that the account would be forwarded to Mr. Hamilton. The repairs comprise:

a. Re-fastening roof battens into position and applying roof cement to joints in metal covering on the main roof; and

b. Patching and applying roof cement to leakages in ready roofing on class room building.

No estimate of cost for temporary repairs has been furnished, but the roofing cement has been purchased and delivered, and by this date work should be completed.

There are no drawings of the Elkhorn Residential School among Indian Affairs record plans, but in view of Mr. Gow's remarks regarding the class room building, we feel that a definite hazard to the safety of pupils and teachers exists.
If the Institution is to continue in operation, major repairs to both the Residential School and the class room building will be required. This will necessitate a complete survey of both structures and their mechanical services to determine the extent and approximate cost of the work involved.

[Signature]

CHIEF ENGINEER.
November 13th, 1944.

Dr. McGill

Re: Elkhorn Indian Residential School, Elkhorn, Manitoba.

Mr. D.B. Gow, of our Dominion Water and Power Bureau staff at Winnipeg, has made a personal inspection of the roof of the above building, and I am attaching herewith a copy of a memorandum from Mr. Mills dated November 9th, which summarizes Mr. Gow's report.

You will note that roof repairs of a temporary character were to be immediately undertaken by the school engineer, and that this work should be completed by this date.

Mr. Gow expresses some concern in regard to the class room building at the school, and which was moved to its present site after a new foundation had been built for it. Apparently this building suffered considerable damage while being moved, with the result that it seems to be structurally unsound. Temporary repairs to the ready roofing of the flat deck is suggested by Mr. Gow. However, the shingles on the sloping sections of the roof appear to be in fair condition.

If this Indian School will continue in operation for any length of time, extensive repairs to both the residential school building and the class room building will be required. In the meantime, Mr. Gow recommends temporary emergency repairs as outlined.

Director.
Ottawa, November 15, 1944.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
538 Dominion Public Building, Winnipeg, Man.

The Department has just received a lengthy report from the Surveys and Engineering Branch with reference to Mr. Gow's examination of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School. Part of this report reads as follows:

"Mr. Gow reports having discussed the matter of immediately necessary repairs with Mr. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies at Winnipeg, and with the Principal and Engineer at the school. It was agreed that roof repairs of a temporary character were to be carried out by the school engineer and that the account would be forwarded to Mr. Hamilton. The repairs comprise:

a. Re-fastening roof battens into position and applying roof cement to joints in metal covering on the main roof, and

b. Patching and applying roof cement to leakages in ready roofing on class room building.

"No estimate of cost for temporary repairs has been furnished, but the roofing cement has been purchased and delivered, and by this date work should be completed".

I presume the above matters are the same as those to which you referred in your letter of the 7th instant. However, I thought it advisable to bring the matter to your attention again.

No doubt, you have discussed the whole situation with Mr. Gow, but it appears that he feels if

Re NEW SCHOOL BUILDING.

All three classes are in this building now, and the change is certainly worthwhile, for it provides two rooms for recreation in the main building. However, I would like to bring to your attention certain improvements that could be made. In the first place, the lighting in all three rooms is decidedly inadequate. The lights should be lowered about two feet, and larger bulbs used. Mrs. Toone's room is certainly too dark, and besides the lights, I would suggest that another window be put in. Another cupboard is needed in her room. I think that green and white reflector about fourteen inches should be put over each light.

The decorators left a good deal of paint on the floors, and two or three coats of paint, or some good linoleum should be provided to make them look nice.

A drinking fountain is needed in the Primary room, and one between the Intermediate and senior rooms. Water is already coming through the ceiling in two of the rooms.

I discussed the question of Fire Protection in the main building with Mr. Hodkinson, and there appears to be ample provision. Is it possible to provide more toilets in the main building, and a new pump for the septic tank just west of the old power house?

There is plenty of blackboard space in the three rooms, and the furnace is certainly large enough to give satisfactory heat. I would suggest that one of the pianos be placed in the Primary room. I understand there is one in the residence. Generally speaking, the school equipment is satisfactory. I shall be glad to give you any information or assistance at anytime.

Clarence Moore
School Inspector
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Repairs - Elkhorn School.

The benches in the dining-room need new tops. Mr. Hiltz will have the work done by his men but requests that we pay for the lumber. It will cost $26.20 and can be secured from the local dealer.

The stock well has partially caved in and a new one should be provided. I understand water can be secured at a depth of 20 ft. The cost would include labor for digging and well bribing. The total cost should not exceed $100.00. Please advise if this work can be proceeded with.

Some of the electric wiring appears in none too good a condition and Mr. Hiltz is afraid of fire. He would like a check-up made by a proper electrician. I have no doubt that this old wiring is dangerous and according to present standards will perhaps be condemned. Please advise if a complete check-up is authorized. This report should be made in two sections -- one outlining the immediate repairs required to keep the electric system in reasonably good condition and the second section outlining the items that must receive attention later but that could be deferred for a time. Re: Plumbing Required - Elkhorn.

In my letter, 209-11 A.C.E., dated November 7th, 1944, I pointed out the need and quoted - "He (Mr. Yates) intimated the complete job would cost in the neighborhood of $550.00."

This was authorized in your letter 1060-5 dated November 14th, 1944.

However I kept at Yates for a quotation and before receiving your authority I got the attached quotation, dated November 9th. It was slightly higher but the first amount was given without any figuring, so I instructed him to proceed.

On January 8th, 1945, I called on my way through Brandon to Elkhorn and Mr. Yates told me that he would have two men at Elkhorn on January 15th and to advise Mr. Hiltz. All the material had arrived and he thought the work could be completed in ten days.

On January 12th I again called to see that all was in order and that day in checking his previous figures on supplies, transportation and wages, he learned that the clerk had omitted the wages, which he estimates to be $150.00. I told him not to proceed with the work and to submit a new quotation. I went through Mr. Yates' estimate book and am convinced the wages, although noted by him, were omitted by his clerk on the quotation. He had all parts listed and priced and to this total the wages should have been added.

I would like to get the job started at once because the extra conveniences are certainly needed. Please advise by radiogramme or air mail if authority is granted. If at all possible I would like the authority before Mr. Yates leaves on Wednesday for the East, so that the work can be started. The total now, as you will note, is $745.00. Mr. Hiltz is supplying accommodation and board.

In my memorandum of October 27, 1944, I enclosed a copy of report of Dr. A. B. Simes, in connection with the above school. In this report Dr. Simes referred to the lack of proper toilet accommodation in the school. On receipt of the report we wrote to Inspector Hamilton in regard to this matter and on November 9 he wrote as follows:

"I found one bowl broken. This, of course, must be removed. The additional four bowls and four baths are needed. Mr. Yates, from Brandon, had men working at Virden and I was able to get his advice concerning the proposed installations. He checked both the boys' and girls' side of the building and agreed that the present arrangements were inadequate. He pointed out the work involved in taking up the cement and renewing old pipe which is practically worn out or clogged. He explained that on work of this nature it was difficult to give a definite price because almost always unforeseen difficulties would arise."

Inspector Hamilton was requested to secure a quotation from Mr. Yates, and in a letter dated January 13, 1945, which reached us this morning, Mr. Hamilton states that he has been endeavouring to secure a quotation from Mr. Yates and has at length succeeded
in doing so. I enclose this for your information. Mr. Hamilton advises that Mr. Yates has the material ready and has also workmen available and that they can commence on Wednesday January 17. Mr. Hamilton urges immediate acceptance of the tender, as he states again that the extra conveniences are definitely needed.

You will note that the total cost, including labour, is $745.00, and I would appreciate receiving your authority to accept Mr. Yates' tender, in order that the work may proceed at once.

Acting Director.

In my memorandum of October 27, 1944, I enclosed a copy of report of Dr. A. B. Simes, in connection with the above school. "I found one bowl broken. This, of course, must be renewed. The additional four bowls and four baths are needed. Mr. Yates, from Brandon, had men working at Virden and I was able to get his advice concerning the proposed installations. He checked both the boys' and girls' side of the building and agreed that the present arrangements were inadequate. He pointed out the work involved in taking up the cement and renewing old pipe which is practically worn out or clogged. He explained that on work of this nature it was difficult to give a definite price because almost always unforeseen difficulties would arise."

Inspector Hamilton was requested to secure a quotation from Mr. Yates, and in a letter dated January 13, 1945, which reached us this morning, Mr. Hamilton states that he has been endeavouring to secure a quotation from Mr. Yates and has at length succeeded

Ottawa, January 19, 1945.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
WINNIPEG, Manitoba.

Mr. Yates, Plumbing and Heating Outfitter of Brandon, Manitoba, called at this office a few moments ago. Mr. Yates pointed out that there was a mistake in the tender he submitted on repair work at the Elkhorn Indian Residential School. The mistake consisted of his failure to submit an item of labour costs amounting to approximately $150.00. If these labour costs are added, the total amount of the tender will be approximately $745.00.

In view of the condition of the Elkhorn School and the criticism to which the Department has been subjected, as the result of our failure to undertake certain repairs at the Institution, it would be appreciated if you did everything humanly possible to have this work started at once. Mr. Yates has promised me that he would wire the firm, issuing instructions for the work to start on Monday morning. It would be appreciated if you could send us back an assurance that the work actually started on this date.

Re: Flooring - Elkhorn School,
Your file 106-0-5, Jan.10/45.

I note flooring is not available. I was in the lumber yard at Elkhorn last week and at that time they thought they could supply 1000 ft. of edge grain hemlock flooring - 4 inches wide. At Brandon, Wade & Sons, Ltd., promised 500 ft. of 4" edge grain hemlock flooring, priced at $92.00 per thousand.

Re: Elk Horn School,

I again visited this School on January 9th and 11th, 1945.

The new fire escape doors have been installed and the dormitory doors hung to open out.

The carpenter was busy retreading the stairway on the boys' side of the building. It will take him at least two weeks to complete the work authorized. The school has engaged a second carpenter and he was busy building cupboards and fixing doors. There is considerable general repair work needed and this man will be kept busy for another month. I understand he is being paid by the Church Commission.

The kitchen tables had arrived, also the 24 chairs.

The work on the plumbing was to start today, January 15th, but due to a mistake in the quotation, has been cancelled. This was reported by an air mail letter.

The septic tank pump is on order and should arrive early in February.

The paint has also arrived. The painting will start after the repair work has been completed.

Flooring in quantity is not available. I understand 1000 ft. is available at Elk Horn, and Wade & Sons of Brandon will supply 800 ft. The amount provided for the material and labor is $1350.00. If flooring cannot be secured I would strongly recommend that part of the money be used as follows:

1. Supply 40 additional mattresses - then all the beds would have suitable mattresses; possible cost ------------------------ $292.00

2. Rewire balance of bed springs - (68). Some of these are tied up with string and wire and the whole lot should be rewired. Possible cost ------------------------ $156.00

3. Basement wall replastered and fixed with burlap approximate cost ------------------------ 100.00

4. Material be supplied to enlarge chapel. The labor will be paid by the Commission. At present the chapel is very small - about 14' x 18'. A storeroom adjacent and about the same size could be added by removing the partition and building...
more seats - also redecorating.
This extra room is really needed because
the present chapel will not nearly
accommodate the pupils.
Hard to estimate ---- perhaps --------- $150.00

5. Pillows needed - 130. At present the boys have
no pillows and those used by the girls
are dirty. They are filled with a
lumpy material which cannot be washed.
Pillow cases are now available at the
school for new pillows.
Approximate cost ------------------ 124.00
(Parkhills)

The laundry work is much better and the bedding has
greatly improved. It is a better color and the beds are much
neater.

The breakfast and noon meals are good. I would like to
see a hot drink served at noon. Supper is lacking in some
respects and in a letter to Mr. Hiltz I have made suggestions
which I think he will accept.

There was no serious sickness, although several were in
bed with colds.

There is still room for improvement in staff. Mr. Hiltz
needs a new teacher to replace Mr. Hodgkinson, who is leaving on
January 31st. He also needs a nurse and a matron. The boys'
supervisor, Mr. Blenhard, is unsuitable and should be replaced.
I have discussed his case with Mr. Alderwood and feel sure the
change will be made very shortly.

Changes are taking place at the Elkhorn School but it
has been difficult to get materials and thus the work drags.
Mr. Hiltz has also been greatly handicapped with a staff, some
of which have not given co-operation. Here again there will be
some changes and I hope within the next two months to report
marked improvements.

Mr. Hiltz appears to be a hard worker. He is anxious
to get things in shape but being accustomed to a different type
of school feels hemmed in and cramped. He apparently is liked
by the pupils and has little trouble with discipline.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
for Manitoba.

Re: Elkhorn Indian Residential School.

I was at the Elkhorn School on March 6th and would report as follows.

The following repairs have been completed and vouchers submitted:

- Porch to outside School.
- Fire Inspector's recommendations carried out.
- Mattresses supplies - 58 - $423.40
- Bed Springs repaired 59 117.88
- Paint supplied 222.07
- 2 doz. Chairs 40.80
- 2 Kitchen Tables 20.42
- Farmer's House decorated 75.12
- New tops supplied for benches in diningroom 25.50
- Stairways repaired, also hallway on boys' side, plaster repaired 401.35
- 1000 ft. of flooring purchased 90.95
- Electrical repairs 272.96

Authority still remains for the sewage pump $576.00; completion of well $100.00; laying of floor and repairs to floor - approximately $30.00.

The sewage pump so urgently needed and authorized cannot be shipped before about May 1st. The original was considered too small and a larger pump is to be supplied at the same price of $576.00. I understand this is being assembled now, but the date of delivery will be about as stated above. I presume this means now a charge against the next fiscal vote, or can it be handled any other way?

The well will be completed in a few days and the vouchers forwarded.

We of course could not begin to get enough flooring. In view of the quality now coming on the market I would recommend that for all halls linoleum be supplied. I would request four rolls of AA quality battleship linoleum, brown, and I enclose Ashdown's quotation. If placed by wire the material should arrive in time to be paid for out of this year's appropriation.

We still need about forty mattresses and if authority were granted these could be supplied within ten days from date of order. If authorized I could get quotations from Parkhill and Globe Bedding.

The plumbing has been well installed and I consider adequate.
The meals have much improved and I am sure can now hardly be justly criticized.

There has been a number of changes in the staff which has greatly improved the situation. A boys' supervisor is still urgently needed.

The rinse tub in the laundry is a galvanized water trough set in a cement base. This trough leaks and should be replaced. I would recommend that a new tub, 30"x30"x20" deep placed on legs, be ordered immediately. I can have such a tub made by Default Sheet Metal Company, St. Boniface, for approximately $25.00, f.o.b. St.Boniface. This tub will be movable and the girls can stand up straight to rinse the clothes instead of reaching down within six inches of their feet. I urge that this piece of equipment be allowed.

I strongly recommend the purchase of linoleum, the rinse tub and extra mattresses, then when the sewerage pump arrives the condition at this institution will be vastly changed as from a year ago.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

I submit the following report on the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, inspected May 15th, 1945.

Mr. Hiltz has been in charge here for about six months, during which time he has made many improvements.

More toilets and bath tubs have been installed and both the rooms are kept cleaner than for many years. Stairways and floors have been repaired and renewed as well as new doors installed. All doors leading from the dormitories have been hung to open out, and the toilets in the four dormitories are all in good condition.

Bed springs have been repaired and new mattresses supplied for 58 beds. The bedding is all well washed and looks clean. The plaster has been repaired and most of the walls and woodwork painted. The electric wiring has been checked and extensive repairs carried out. A number of chairs were purchased, also two work tables for the kitchen, and a new rinse tub for the laundry. Four rolls of battle ship linoleum have been supplied and this will be laid as soon as possible. In addition to all these repairs, the children are better clothed and undoubtedly much better fed. I discussed the meals with Dr. Johnson and he stated, "I often visit the school at meal time and I have no hesitation in saying the children are now well fed." At present they obtain from three to four hundred pounds of milk per day and this is all given to the children. Mr. Hiltz also purchases 40 dozen eggs each month and these provide a change for at least three meals. He now has 250 baby chicks and hopes during the coming year to produce the eggs needed at the school.

Perhaps the greatest change is in the attitude of the staff and pupils. The children appear very content and happy and for months no child has attempted to run away. The staff members are interested in their work and some of the members, after doing their regular work, gave up many evenings to help with the painting.

We are still waiting for the delivery of the septic tank pump and when it arrives Mr. Yates, from Brandon, will install it at once. In spite of all these improvements there is yet much to do and I present the following recommendations for immediate consideration:

1. The sewage disposal field must be fenced away from the stock, and I enclose a sketch showing the proposed change. The following fencing is required:

| 900 yds. of 7-strand paige fence, 42" high @ 40¢ per rod | -72.00   |

| Braces for corners, 4x6                                  | -20.00   |
| Gate - 16 ft. (Ashdowns)                                | -10.75   |
| Staples, 100 lbs.                                        | -5.10    |

Total: $177.85
2. Hog wire to make runs for present stock of pigs

- 20 rods of 32" hog fence
  Ashdowns 08-52-33 @ 43¢ per rod
  $6.60

3. Poultry fence "Bantam" Ashdowns

- 20 rods @ $6.25 per 10-red roll
  $12.50

Total for fencing $205.20

4. The old chicken house has not been used for many years except as a junk shop. The frame work is fairly good, but it needs re-lining, insulation, complete new windows and a cement floor. In addition, Mr. Hiltz would like to enlarge the building by a 10-ft. addition in length, which means an addition of 10x16. The material required is estimated as follows:

|---------------|------|
| Cement        | $70.00 |

5. The hog pen, horse barn and cow barn all need certain repairs. The doors should be renewed, cement work repaired, certain partitions renewed, track hangers need replacing. These repairs are listed as follows:

| Item                                      | Cost |
|-------------------------------------------|------|
| Lumber for 12 barn doors, large & small   | $60.00 |
| Hangers                                   | $20.00 |
| Track                                     | $12.00 |
| Corner boards and ceiling                 | $50.00 |
| Cement for barn and pig pen               | $10.00 |
| Lumber for pig pen                        | $15.00 |

Total $167.00

6. The outside classrooms (3) in one building are very cold in windy weather. This building should be made warm before next winter sets in. It should be covered with asphalt brick siding, or insul brick siding, or cement stucco. The estimated cost of material will be forwarded when received.

The furnace still appears too small to heat the school. I have asked Mr. Yates to look into this and submit a recommendation. I found the windows all very loose and no doubt if these were re-fitted much heat could be saved. I would recommend that the Department allow $200.00 to pay for labor in refitting all windows, repairing storm sashes, and installing insulation. The insulation would be an additional expense but I believe would be well worth while.

I am quite aware that these recommendations entail considerable expense but the Department know the condition of the school, and this condition can only be improved if we secure the necessary funds. I do hope immediate approval can be given to all these matters so that Mr. Hiltz may proceed at once with the work.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

CANADA
I was at the Elkhorn Indian Residential School on September 26th, 1945.

The School is now in charge of Rev. Mr. Dixon. He has only been there about three months but already appears to have a fair grasp of the situation. He has a new Matron, Miss Beanland, who has been loaned from a school in Alberta. She is a graduate nurse and appears very capable.

The School has been greatly improved as the result of the work done by Mr. Hiltz. The halls and many of the rooms have been painted, and all the halls are covered with linoleum.

The children are well dressed and neat in appearance.

The dormitories were clean and the beds neatly made.

The nurse has prepared a menu which appears carefully planned. I believe the children now are well fed.

The new septic tank pump has been installed. It works well and has plenty of capacity. I was very pleased with the pump and with the splendid job Mr. Yates made in installing it. Twenty minutes in operation twice a day empties the tank. The disposal from this tank has been a big problem for almost a year and this long awaited pump is indeed a welcome necessity.

The farm crop is light. They have no garden and so it will be necessary to purchase all the vegetables. Already the new Principal is ploughing garden land for next year and he plans on producing plenty for the School. The garden at this School has been neglected for years; but I believe from now on this work will receive special attention.

The work on the electric wiring is still not completed. The demand for electricians is very keen due to the program of rural electrification by the Provincial Government and so all such workers have more than they can do. I am yet hopeful of having the work completed before winter.

The barns and outbuildings need considerable repairing. A number of doors need to be renewed and glass is needed for several windows.

The Farming Instructor, Mr. Dahl, certainly has not measured up to his responsibility and is being relieved of his duties. I hope the School will be more successful in their next selection.

A.G.Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Ottawa, 16th October, 1945.

I quote the following extracts from a letter received from Dr. Alderwood and signed by his Assistant Secretary, Mr. Forward.

School roof:
"The tin on the roof has cracked and given away in many places as well as pulling through nailheads and is permitting the entry of water. The eaves surrounding the roof have warped and in some cases fallen completely away from the studdings and permit the passage of cold air unrestricted throughout the top storey. This situation makes heating a most difficult matter as well as encouraging further deterioration to the studding, plaster, and paint on the interior. The roof is felt to be the most important factor in the entire repair requisition and we stress the urgency of immediate inspection and action."

School, Main Building:
"The exterior wood-work throughout the school needs repainting. There are evidences of dry-rot affecting the sills and it is felt that painting at once would save a far more costly operation of replacing the sills and sashes at a later date. Five Hundred and Fifty Feet of Thirty Inch screening is required to place the building in a fly-proof condition."

Dormitories:
"Five Dormitories, the Infirmary and the Sewing Room should be re-floored or at least have the necessary floor repairs made and a covering allowed. The sizes of the Dormitories and rooms are as follows:

A. Dormitory..................1,152 square feet.
B. Dormitory..................1,152 square feet.
C. Dormitory..................1,152 square feet.
D. Dormitory..................1,152 square feet.
E. Dormitory..................1,216 square feet.
Infirmary....................600 square feet.
Sewing-room..................360 square feet.

These floors have splintered under wear, throughout the many years past and in some cases have been worn as thin as one quarter inch. It would be useless to merely cover such spots with Battleship Linoleum without first effecting repairs. The floors in their present condition are what may be described as a colossal problem to keep in a clean and sanitary condition and it has been my personal experience to see children attempting to clean their dormitory and sewing-room..."
floors by picking up each bit of fluff or thread ends in their fingers instead of being able to use a mop."

Principal's Residence:

The exterior requires painting very greatly and it is requested that the following materials be supplied for the operation: Fifteen Gallons of Green Shingle Paint, Fifteen Gallons of Brown Shingle Paint and Ten Gallons of White Exterior Paint."

Farm Buildings:

We feel that the school main building is of prime consideration this year and feel also that the Department is providing a Manual Training Instructor for the school that repairs to the Farm Buildings could well be undertaken by the Manual Training Instructor as organized training projects for his pupils. At this time therefore, we make no requisition for repairs to the Farm Buildings but ask that it be kept in mind that repairs are imminent and we may require assistance in the form of lumber and material."

The condition of the school roof has been reported on before and a year or so ago Mr. Gow of the Surveys and Engineering Branch made an inspection and suggested temporary repairs which I believe were carried out. I would recommend that Mr. Gow make a further inspection and submit a report with definite recommendations for a permanent repair job.

The exterior of the school certainly is in need of painting and this was mentioned in my report of May 14th.

The condition of the floor is bad and authority was granted last year to purchase flooring. Material was not available and I doubt if Maple flooring can yet be secured.

The 520 feet of screening should be supplied. The screens will then be repaired and remade at the school.

The paint should be supplied for the exterior of the Principal's residence. No mention was made of labor so I presume this will be supplied by the school.

The repair work outlined will involve heavy expense but should be undertaken without delay.

With reference to your letter of July 12th and the report of Mr Moodie, Fire Inspector, I am unable to find anyone willing to undertake the recommendations in section 4 of the report, namely, putting extra protection under the kitchen stove. For your information I may say that our kitchen stove is some twenty feet long, three feet high and three feet wide and it is set in a concrete base. The floor in front of the stove is protected by thick metal. If Mr. Moodie's advice is followed we will have to have a new kitchen stove as this one will not stand any moving.

Shortly after taking up my appointment in July 1945 I asked Inspector A.G. Hamilton to have the school roof fixed, the eaves re-built and the exterior of the school painted. I repeated this request in May of 1946 and still nothing has been done. The roof leaks badly and the rain is spoiling every ceiling on the top storey. If rain is able to come in it is obvious that heat can go out and we are still attempting to heat the building with a boiler which blew a section in 1938. During the winter we burn a ton and a half of coal a day and yet we hear criticism about the cold building. Can something be done about this?

Yours truly,

The Rev. B.O.G. Dixon

Re: Roof on Elkhorn School,
Your file 106-0-5 WTL August 6/46.

Attached is a quotation by Mr. Ziegler of the Central Sheet Metal Works, Brandon, on renewing the roof of the Elkhorn School.

Mr. Gow of the Dominion Water Power Bureau had Mr. Ziegler repair the school roof at the Brandon School some five or six years ago, and the work was satisfactory. He also examined the roof of the Elkhorn School along with Mr. Gow two years ago, and on his advice certain repairs were done, which made it possible for us to carry on. I consider Mr. Ziegler a reliable person and the fact that the Johns-Manville Company is willing him to handle their roofing and will give a 20 year bonded roof indicates his work is satisfactory.

The present metal roof is very loose and badly cracked. Mr. Ziegler said it was much worse than when he last examined it. He was surprised that the heavy winds had not ripped it off, especially on the west side. In some places it has bulged off from the roof from six to eight inches. This buckling from the roof allows it to move up and down with the wind and of course this causes cracks. It also leaks around the nail heads. The school was built about 50 years ago and this is the original roof.

Mr. Ziegler's price is on a Johns-Manville Company built up roof and in a second letter he states how this will be done. Mr. Ziegler is prepared to do the work if it is started soon before the cold weather. A new roof is essential and I recommend Mr. Ziegler be instructed to proceed with the work at once.

I attach a rough sketch showing the type of roof and plan of surface. It is only the top area dealt with in Mr. Ziegler's quotation. The steep sides are covered with a light weight tin. The paint has almost entirely disappeared and most of the area is badly rusted. This portion should be scraped or brushed with a steel brush, treated with a rust resisted paint, and then painted. This work is important and if not done we will find ourselves faced with another roofing job. I have asked for a quotation on this work from Mr. Baker, a local painter, living in Elkhorn. As soon as his quotation arrives I will send it forward. I would, however, point out that the portion of the roof referred to is very high from the ground. It is steep and...
There is between 5 and 6 hundred feet of this wall which is covered with tin. It is badly rusted and needs to be scraped and painted first with a primer to prevent rusting and then with the Bristol paint—the desired color.

Re: Elkhorn School.

As pointed out in my letter dated August 28, the new roof was for the top area only and not for the steep sides. This area does need painting and in connection with this Mr. Baker writes as follows:

"One coat of paint applied to fourth story of school building, trim and window sashes, (not including storm-sashes) including rubbing off rust spots; labor only $120.00. Second coat as above $75.00.

We have very carefully inspected this roof and it is my firm opinion one coat would do a good job here. There are actually very few rust spots, what appears to be rust is the old red paint. I believe there is no object in loading sheet metal with too much paint, as it has been my experience that it peels and blisters under the sun. However should you desire two coats I will apply the second coat for $75.00.

We paint storm-sashes at the rate of 90¢ per hour (labor only) replacing putty and glass where necessary. The condition of these is so variable that it is difficult to form a satisfactory estimate."

There is a large area to cover and you will note it is around the fourth story of the building. A difficult and dangerous place to work. I consider the price for labor of $120.00 very reasonable.
This metal sloping roof was painted red before and no doubt it would be best to stay with that color—perhaps tending to a maroon rather than bright red. I understand special paint is required for metal.

The surface to be covered consists approximately of 5,000 square feet and the Painter, Mr. Baker states it will require 18 gallons. I would suggest that four, 5 gallon tins be purchased.

I wrote Mr. Dixon on December 16th as follows:

"Please obtain estimates on the following:
1. the provision of a storm door for Miss Fry's room. You of course know all doors must open out to meet fire regulations.
2. How many storm sashes do you require for the school building - give size and price?
3. Get estimate on repairing ceilings in the three classrooms.

"A prompt reply will be appreciated as the information is needed by Ottawa."

On January 4th, after my second letter, he replied as follows:

"I have delayed replying to your letter of December 16th until such time as I could give you worthwhile estimates.

1. This item has been attended to by the Manual Training Shop at no cost to the Department.
2. Storm Sashes .... four 26x28 - 2 light, three 12x26-- 4 light.
   No price can be obtained locally.
3. The trouble here is not with the ceiling but with the roof which is completely finished. Not only is the actual roofing finished but all the supporting structure, joists, etc., are gone and it is just the right which keeps it in place. This building is one of the original frame buildings of 1889 first erected in Elkhorn, saved from the fire of 1895, then moved here in 1897 when the present main building was erected. When the classrooms were constructed in 1943-44 the poor condition of the top floor evidently escaped notice. The ceilings in the classrooms are wallboard."

The roof referred to is not the roof on the main building but rather on an outbuilding which some years ago was converted into three classrooms. I have no doubt the roof could be re-inforced by installing extra rafters or taken off altogether and replace with all new material. I pointed out some year ago that the building was cold and might be greatly improved by two layers of paper, wired and stuccoed."
I hardly think it necessary to send out a man from the Surveys and Engineering Branch just to check on this building but if there is other work in this Province for which his services are required then this could be done at the same time.

A.G. Hamilton

Elkhorn School

I was at Elkhorn School April 21st but did not submit a report because at that time I expected shortly to be leaving for Ottawa. However, the trip East appears to be indefinite and I consider it advisable to forward at once the following report. The repairs needed are as follows:

1. The lower slope of the mansard roof, which is covered with metal roofing, is rusted - the original paint has practically all disappeared. This portion of the roof requires painting. The boards under the eave have rotted and in places some of the boards have fallen off. The eaves should be repaired before the roof is painted.

2. The Principal states it was impossible to heat the school during the past winter. It is my understanding that the present boiler was installed years ago - since then the west wing has been added to the building, which undoubtedly overloaded the capacity of the boiler. Some few years ago one section of the boiler sprung a leak and instead of renewing the section it was closed off, which procedure further increased the load on the remaining sections of the boiler. I have no doubt a new boiler is needed. I would recommend that a qualified engineer visit this school and make a thorough investigation of the heating system and report on the advisability of a new boiler.

3. Many windows are loose which, of course, makes it more difficult in the winter to heat the school. Satisfactory results might be obtained by the use of material known as Flexotite.

4. The classrooms, three in all, are in a building detached from the main residence. This building needs extensive repairs and I would recommend that a qualified engineer inspect the school and submit a report. The roof leaks in numerous places. In my opinion the composition roofing is finished and should be removed and where necessary new rafters and roof boards be supplied. The entire surface then should be recovered with a built-up asphalt roof. The windows need repairing and refitting. This work must not be neglected longer, otherwise, the interior walls and ceiling will be destroyed.

5. A new coal shed is needed. The present building is useless and should be wrecked.

6. Repair work is needed on all the barns. New doors should be made and properly hung. The ceiling in the cow barn should be renailed and a quantity of new boards supplied.
7. The linoleum on the steps leading from the basement to the dormitories is breaking in many places - right angle metal should be supplied so that the edges of the linoleum can be fastened down. The use of such metal would lengthen the life of the linoleum many years.

8. The chesterfield in the staff sitting room is in a disgraceful condition and I am sure past repairing. I would recommend that a new chesterfield and two well built occasional chairs be supplied.

9. The Principal's residence needs exterior painting - both the roof and the walls. I have just now received a quotation from Mr. Baker of Elkhorn covering this work, as well as the painting of the school roof referred to above in section one. I am enclosing a copy of Mr. Baker's quotation.

I know this list of repairs and requirements is long and will involve considerable expense. However, the Department is well aware that this is an old school and has reached the stage where extensive repairs cannot be avoided. I have listed the major requirements and recommend that all be favourably considered.

Yours truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Further to our memorandum of June 18, 1947, in connection with the above, you are advised that we are in receipt of survey plans and a report dated July 26, 1947, prepared by Mr. W.H. Wallace of Mr. Dew's office.

The present gravity system of hot water heating is of ancient vintage, and the piping system is one of mediocre design. The boiler has apparently outlived its usefulness and for a considerable time has been operating below its capacity on account of one damaged section, which has had to be disconnected. The addition of the new wing at the west end of the building has further increased the load which this boiler is required to handle.

After having given thorough consideration to the requirements based on Mr. Wallace's data, it is our opinion that the piping system need not be replaced but minor alterations in the boiler room will be necessary.

We have checked over the radiators in each and every room in the building, and find that in most cases they are of sufficient size and in some cases, oversized. It is not our intention however, to reduce the size of any of these units. The existing piping system is of a design which cannot be expected to provide circulation to all parts of the building by gravity. Even if the boiler was sufficiently large, proper distribution would be difficult to obtain.

With up-to-date technical data relative to the laws governing the flow of hot water and with the development of new and efficient circulating pumps and controls of proven efficiencies, it is felt that instead of tearing out the existing piping system, a satisfactory solution could be obtained by converting from a gravity flow to a forced circulated system by the use of a few items of modern equipment.

We are, therefore, recommending that the following operations be carried out in order that the building may be properly heated:

1. Remove existing boiler and replace with new square sectional cast iron hot water heating boiler of sufficient capacity.

2. Recondition existing stoker carrying out repairs which may be necessary and reset under new boiler.

3. Install new centrifugal type circulating pump of the proper capacity for the purpose of circulating water at a rate calculated to carry heat to all parts of the building.

4. Provide and install necessary elementary controls in connection with stoker operation, circulating pump operation and boiler protection.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

5. Provide and install additional return piping required in connection with improved circulation.

6. Supply and install square head cocks on each return line with permanently located thermometers, thereby making it possible to equalize circulation to all parts of the building.

Since this school was built in 1897, it is more than likely that windows and doors could be weather-stripped to advantage. It is recommended that this operation be carried out.

Apart from this weather-stripping, we have estimated that the revisions to the heating system will cost in the neighborhood of $5,000, and when advised by Indian Affairs to proceed, we will issue plans and specifications to Mr. Gov., asking him to obtain prices and submit same to this Service for consideration.

It is pointed out that delivery on the boiler and some other items may be eleven to twelve weeks, and if it is desired to complete this work in time for the coming heating season, an early decision should be reached.

The work outlined in these specifications and shown on the accompanying drawing, Index No. Sheet No., is intended to be carried out by a General Contractor who in this case will be the Stonefitter. He shall engage all necessary sub-contractors and skilled mechanics to do all work not relative to his own and shall be responsible for the successful carrying out and completion of all the work involved.

In addition to the scope of work above which covers alterations and revisions to the heating system, it is hereby pointed out that some minor structural changes may be involved. It is possible that the existing boiler pit may have to be enlarged in which case work shall be included in this contract.

As this project is of an urgent nature, the Contractor will be required to engage skilled men in the numbers required to carry out the work with a minimum of delay, in order that it may be completed and ready for operation not later than October.

The Department will not enter into any correspondence with sub-contractors or tradesmen all such matters pertaining to the job as may arise during the course of the work shall be between the General Contractor and the Department.

In submitting his estimate covering the complete installation, the General Contractor shall enclose his marked cheque for 10% of the amount, made payable to the Receiver General of Canada. At the time a contract is awarded, cheques will be returned to unsuccessful contractors.

Progress payments up to 85% of the approximate value of the work based on monthly progress estimates, will be made at monthly intervals, with the remaining 10% being retained as a hold back until final completion and acceptance of the work by the Department.

In order to accelerate progress of the work, the Department is prepared to render such constructive advice as the Contractor may require during the progress of the works.

All correspondence shall be addressed to:

T.S. Hillis,

OTTAWA, Ontario.
1. Scope of Work

This specification and the accompanying plans are intended to provide for revisions to the boiler room equipment as follows:

(a) Disconnect and remove existing square sectional hot water heating boiler, and dispose same as directed.

(b) Disconnect and remove existing expansion tank now located on the 3rd floor and remove risers to same.

(c) Disconnect and re-arrange present piping connections in boiler room as hereinafter described and shown on the drawing.

(d) Provide and connect up one new cast iron square sectional hot water heating system boiler of a type and capacity as hereinafter specified.

(e) Provide and connect up one new centrifugal type circulating pump, direct connected to a standard motor all as hereinafter described and as shown on the drawing.

(f) Provide and install in boiler room where shown on drawing, one new compression tank of a size hereinafter described.

(g) Thoroughly clean existing boiler and reset under new boiler. Boiler shall be tested for mechanical defects and parts which are found to be defective shall be replaced.

(h) Provide and install all other miscellaneous items of equipment, controls, etc., as shown on drawing and/or hereinafter specified.

2. Verify the Site

The Contractor must visit the site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

3. Material and Workmanship

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects (except as otherwise specified or noted on plans).

Workmanship shall be of the best and all work shall be done in a neat manner with due attention being given to the grading of pipes and making connections. All connections shall be made so as to permit free and unobstructed flow at all times, and adequate provision shall be made for expansion.

4. Valves

All valves, up to and including 2" in size shall be gate valves, all brass; those over 2" shall be iron Sally, bronze fitted, of a type and make satisfactory to the Chief Engineer or his representative.

5. Piping

All hot water flow and return piping shall be standard black steel pipe put together with cast iron screwed fittings and with concentric reducing couplings and unions.

Plunged connections may be used to connect new circulating pump which is located at the rear of the new boiler.

All piping shall be carefully runned before assembly and all pipe compound shall be applied to pipe threads only.

Piping shall be installed substantially as shown on drawing with due consideration being given to avoiding structural obstacles which may be found on the job.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
6. HEATING AND COOLING

Where exposed new piping passes through partitions or ceilings in finished rooms, they shall be provided with galvanized iron sleeves 1" larger than pipes and shall have flanged ends.

A cast iron or chrome plated pressed steel connection of the same pipe or split ring type shall be provided and installed where any pipe enters or emerges from a ceiling, floor or wall.

7. GRADING OF PIPES

All new floor and return piping shown on the drawing shall be graded so that it may be immediately drained at low points.

8. RETURN PIPES

Supply and install additional return mains where shown on drawing end of a line on note. This will involve three new pipes which shall in each case be carried up to the top floor and connected to the stub serving the radiator in a manner shown on details. The object of these new return lines is to help equalize the circulation. These pipe lines shall be run adjacent to existing work and shall be supported by hangers similar to those now in use, and the new return main shall be located at approximately the same level as the existing work with due attention being given to its proper grade.

9. AUTOMATIC AIR VENTS

Provide and install where indicated on plan, automatic air vents of an approved make having heavy cast iron body, seamless copper float and needle type discharge valve.

Vents shall be of sufficient capacity to positively and quickly relieve the air from all parts of the system. Vent outlets shall be carried to the nearest drain or as otherwise directed.

10. BOILERS

Disconnect and remove existing boiler, and store on the premises where directed. Provide and install one new square sectional cast iron hot water heating boiler equal to Board-Register No. 452, having a net rating of not less than 6400 square ft. of hot water radiation. This boiler shall be set on 18" brick base in the existing boiler pit. Boiler shall be equipped with pressure gauge, thermometer, direct-acting, and reverse-acting automatics, all as shown on the drawings; drain cut valve, pressure regulating and pressure relief valves on cold water supply, all connected in accordance with Isometric sketch on drawing.

11. STOKER

The existing stoker shall be dismantled and thoroughly cleaned and inspected for mechanical defects. Any work that is found necessary to put stoker into first class operating condition, shall be carried out as part of this contract. Stoker shall be reset under new boiler and when the installation is completed its operation shall be thoroughly tested.

12. COMPRESSION TANK

Provide and install where shown on plan in boiler room, one new compression tank 24 inches in diameter by 72 inches long. Tank shall be provided with gauge glass, drain connections and additional saddles as shown and called for on drawing. Mount tank approximately 6' from boiler room ceiling using 2" by 1/4" thick strap iron hangers securely bolted to ceiling. This tank shall be subjected to an hydrostatic test of 100 lbs per square inch and shall be built in accordance with Interprovincial Regulations covering pressure vessels.
15. CIRCULATING PUMP

Furnish and install where shown on drawing, one centrifugal circulating pump equal in all respects to that made by the B & O model G No. 6 supplied by the B & O Armstrong Co., Ltd., of Toronto, Canada. This pump shall be direct connected to a one horse power single phase, D.C. motor, 60 cycle, 240 volt, standard motor complete with all necessary switches and etc. Pump and motor shall be mounted on an integral cast iron base which shall be set on a 1" wood coping and 1" cork base, the whole being covered by another boiler grated into basement floor slab. This unit shall have a capacity to deliver 110 U.S. gal per minute against 30 feet head. Pump shall be connected generally as shown on Isometric sketch with a valued bypass to permit gravity circulation should the pump be out of service. On the discharge side of the pump and at a point where shown, install a straight pattern flow control valve equal to No. 60 as supplied by B & O Armstrong Co., Ltd., of Toronto, Canada.

16. PIPE CONNECTIONS AT BOILER

Pipe and return connections in the boiler room shall be re-arranged as shown on the drawing breaking into existing lines approximately where indicated and sized in accordance with notations on plan. Each return main shall be provided with a thermometer reading up to 200°F and installed in a separable well. Each return line shall also be provided with a square hood cock for adjusting the flow to the various circuits. These square hood cocks shall be installed approximately where shown on the Isometric sketch and when piping has been completed the contractor shall adjust the cocks, until each thermometer reads approximately the same temperature.

17. CONTROLS

Provide and mount near front of boiler where shown on drawing, one direct-acting thermostat with external adjustment and visible scale. This thermostat shall be connected to boiler motor to control boiler operation.

Provide also a boiler timer relay to maintain low fire.

Provide and install at rear of boiler where shown on drawing, one reverse acting controller.

Provide and install one line voltage thermostat and locate same on west wall of dining room. The thermostat shall be provided with a heavy cast iron thermostat guard securely mounted to prevent tampering. The thermostat shall be wired into the pump circuit to control operation of the circulating pump.

The reverse acting controller referred to above, shall be so wired into the pump and thermostat circuits that it will over ride the thermostat and start the pump when the boiler water rises to 200°F.

18. ROOFING

Remove present slate roofing and replace with new 16" diameter by 16 gauge galvanized iron slate pipe. Support same on approved hangers spaced at approximately 6 foot centres, and securely fastened to basement ceiling.

19. COVERING

Boiler shall be covered 1" thick with 4 ply asbestos air cell blocks wired in place and plastered 1" thick with long fibre asbestos cement applied in two coats, the last coat to be tempered with 10% Portland cement and trowelled to a smooth finish. Paint two coats with waterproof paint of an approved colour. New piping shall be covered to match existing work.

20. MISCELLANEOUS

If it is found necessary to enlarge the existing boiler pit to accommodate the installation of the new boiler, it shall be done as part of this contract. All miscellaneous items of piping not specifically mentioned but which are intended to complete this hookup shall be provided and installed by the contractor. All valves up to 6" shall be all brass gate valves. All valves 6" and over shall be iron body bronze fitted gate valves of an approved make satisfactory to the Chief Engineer or his representative.

19. **DRAINAGE**

Shop drawings shall be submitted in triplicate to this Service for the approval of the Chief Engineer. This shall include circulating pump, with pump curves showing performance. The contractor shall state the make of the boiler he contemplate using and submit catalogue data giving all its characteristics and capacity.

All items of control equipment herein before specified shall be equal to those made by Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Co., of Canada Limited.

20. **CLEANUP**

Upon completion of the work the contractor shall remove all rubbish and waste materials from his work and leave the whole system in perfect working order.

21. **RECORD KEEPING**

During the progress of the work the contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans.

Upon completion he shall forward one set of blueprints with changes clearly recorded in red to the Chief Engineer. Blueprints for this purpose will be furnished by the Department. No changes to the plan will be permitted without the written authority of the Chief Engineer. The departmental representative shall be consulted with regard to any proposed changes and he shall procure the necessary authority if deemed advisable.

22. **GUARANTEE**

The contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance by the Department. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period, at his own expense as soon as possible after having been notified in writing that such defect has occurred.

Re: Nikhorn Indian Residential School

An officer from Mr. Gow's staff carried out an inspection of the Heating System at the above, last July and submitted his report to this Service. Having analysed the report, plans and specifications were prepared by this Service and Mr. Gow was requested to obtain tenders for the work outlined therein. The following is a condensed summary of the proposals received from Mr. Gow:

| Firm                        | Location       | Price          | Proposal                                      |
|-----------------------------|----------------|----------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Yates and Company           | Brandon, Man.  | No estimate    | Contract or time and material.                |
| Relf Plumbing & Heating     | Brandon, Man.  | Not stated     | Cost plus 10%                                 |
| Neale, Stothard & Chapman   | Brandon, Man.  | $5,260.47      | Firm tender for immediate acceptance          |
| John Plaxton & Co., Ltd.    | Winnipeg, Man. | $6,150.00      | Cost plus 10%                                 |
| Randall & Co., Ltd.         | Winnipeg, Man. | $6,551.00      | Firm tender for immediate acceptance          |

It is our considered opinion that Messrs. Neale, Stothard & Chapman, have offered the most favourable proposal. Our own estimate for this work was $8,000.00.

Since Yates and Company and Relf Plumbing & Heating give no estimate of the cost in their proposals, it is felt that their prices could conceivably exceed the firm tender of $5,260.47, on a cost plus 10%, or time and material basis.

It is pointed out that Messrs. Neale, Stothard & Chapman, reserve the right to invoice materials at the time of delivery, which would increase their figure, if prices over which they have no control increase. This is in line with Dominion Government policy which states that a contractor shall not be penalised owing to price changes, over which he has no control, which may occur between the time a tender is accepted and deliveries of materials are made.

Therefore, it is our recommendation that this work be awarded to Messrs. Neale, Stothard & Chapman, on the basis of their firm tender and that a memorandum be prepared to cover same.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,

Department of Mines and Resources,

Departmental Estimates 1948-49
Anglican Indian Residential School,

We have just received the following from the Principal of our School at Elkhorn in reply to my request for a report on services needed at that School:

(a) New Hot Water Boiler

The present boiler leaks badly and is beyond repair. A new 800-gallon boiler is needed.

(b) Manual Training Shop

A building 30' x 25' x 8' is needed. Approximate cost of materials - $1,500.00

(c) New Roof on School Block

Plans and estimates have been prepared by the Surveys and Engineering Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources.

(d) New Electric Motor

1 H.P. single phase 110-220 volt, 60 cycle, 1725 R.F.M., stoker motor is continually breaking down.

(e) Fencing Material

5000 fence posts
6 rolls barbed wire
2 single 14' farm gates
We shall be glad if you will provide for as much of the above work as you possibly can in your 1948-49 Estimates.

The Principal reports that, as tenders have already been sent to your Branch covering the installation of a new heating system, he has not included this item.

I understand that you propose to use the $500 provided in your current year's Estimates for the heating system mentioned in the preceding paragraph. If there is sufficient balance remaining after the heating system is installed, will you please give consideration to the early provision of the new hot water boiler mentioned in (a) above instead of deferring this until the next financial year. I am sure you agree that a leaky hot water boiler beyond repair should be replaced as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner

The undersigned has the honour to report:

That under Vote 161 of the 1947-1948 estimates of the Department of Mines and Resources, funds have been provided for revisions and additions to the existing hot water heating system in the Pikangikum Indian Residential School in the Province of Ontario.

That tenders were invited, on the basis of drawings and specifications prepared by the Department, from reliable firms in the area who were in a position to bid, through the medium of the Dominion Water Power Bureau in Winnipeg.

That bona-fide lump sum tenders for the work were received from the firms for total amounts as follows:

| Name of Contractor | Total Amount |
|-------------------|--------------|
| Boole, Stothard and Chapman, Brandon, Manitoba | $5,200.00 |
| Randall and Co., Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba | $6,500.00 |

That additional tenders, not in accordance with instructions to tenderors, were received as follows:

Tates and Company, Brandon, Manitoba who offered to carry out the work on the basis of time and materials, but submitted no estimate.

Held Plumbing and Heating, Brandon, Manitoba, who offered to carry out the work on the basis of cost plus 10%, with no estimate stated.

That the bona-fide tenders were analysed and found to be in accordance with the drawings, specifications and tendering documents prepared by the Department, and that the tender furnished by Boole, Stothard and Chapman, of Brandon was accompanied by the required security deposit.

The work is considered to be of an urgent character and the undersigned, therefore, has the honour to recommend that he be authorized to accept the lowest tender, furnished by Boole, Stothard and Chapman of Brandon, Manitoba, and to enter into a contract with that firm for the revisions and additions to the heating system in the building hereinbefore named, in accordance with drawings and specifications prepared by the Department, and the contractor's estimate of Five Thousand Two Hundred and Sixty Dollars and Forty Seven Cents ($5,200.00) which with provision for contingencies and supervision, will entail a total expenditure of funds to the approximate amount of Six Thousand Dollars ($6,000.00) the said expenditure to be net from the appropriate vote of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

Dear Sir:

Re: Existing electrical wiring

The writer has examined the wiring on the above premises and reports as follows:

The original wiring in the residence building was rigid conduit well installed. However, a hazardous condition has developed through additions and extensions being improperly installed with BX cable.

Trouble that developed recently in the BX cable run to the stoker was due to a ground developing in the cable which in turn had become isolated through the service equipment ground being destroyed.

In view of the above, the following alterations are recommended:

1. Replace BX cable in the basement and extensions on fire alarm system with rigid conduit.
2. Service equipment at residential building and service equipment in original power plant building to be grounded with approved type ground rods and fittings.

The above is to be considered urgent and given immediate attention.
