Chief Bignell and Councillor Constant from The Pas Band called at my office December 30th and complained re conditions at Elkhorn School - conditions, which they stated, developed since Mr. Dixon left. They were leaving that night for Elkhorn and I promised I would inspect the school during the first week in January. I have just returned from my inspection today. The complaints listed by the Chief and Councillor were as follows:

1. Clothing poor - supply of socks insufficient - no rubbers, no mitts, no overshoes for the girls - no caps for the boys.
2. Children with head lice.
3. No proper toilet soap and as the water is very hard the children's hands were rough and sore.
4. The milk was like water and the supply very limited.
5. Food in short supply - no butter or eggs.
6. Girl's feet froze and had to be amputated - another girl froze fingers and nails came off.
7. A boy punished and not fed for two weeks.
8. No lard or butter on the table.
9. Parcels sent to kids not delivered when received.
10. Jam etc., spread too thin.
11. No change of clothing since Mr. Dixon left.
12. Bedding not clean and no pillow cases.

I will report on the complaints in the order as set down above:

1. Children have stockings and socks. Boys wear boots but neither boys nor girls have rubbers nor overshoes. None of the senior boys are provided with heavy gum rubbers - a type of footwear usually provided at all schools. I consider rubbers and overshoes essential.
2. Both boys and girls have had head lice and boys also have body lice. The girls are reported clean now - the boys are not in this fortunate condition. This condition should not exist.
3. Toilet soap is usually supplied but there is none at present. There is liquid soap and chunks of pink and white Castile soap but the children claim the soap is strong and in hard water it makes their hands rough and sore. A good toilet soap (hard water) should be provided.
4. The supply of milk amounts to about 80 pounds a day or 32 quarts. The milk is from Holstein cows and after it is put through a separator it looks like milky water. The children do not get the equivalent to a cup a day, in fact, scarcely enough for the morning porridge. Dry whole milk should be supplied to supplement for that produced at the school. All children should have at least a cup at noon instead of cold water and, in addition, enough for their porridge. It should be whole milk—not skim milk.

5. The short supply of food to me appeared as follows:

a. No butter
b. Lard—but spread on too sparingly
c. Jam, peanut butter etc.,—used too sparingly.

I think the children get enough potatoes, bread and stew with a fair amount of good meat. They get no eggs, canned tomatoes or raw fruit.

6. Two girls ran away from the school and when found it was discovered that the one girl had her foot badly frozen. The toe nails came off but are growing back on and the skin is healed and appears healthy. The other girl's fingers were not frozen enough to require any medical attention.

7. The boy referred to was punished by the Principal and sent to bed without supper. He only missed one meal.

8. Lard is spread on the bread before it comes to the table.

9. One parcel though to be a Christmas present was kept until Christmas and then handed out with other Christmas parcels. This parcel was not meant for Christmas and, of course, should have been given as soon as received.

10. Jam and other spreads issued too sparingly.

11. Clothing is changed each week—on bath night.

12. Boys' sheets washed one week and the girls' the next week. A few pillow cases are missing. I understand the allotment ran short but a new supply is expected.

I think most of the trouble is due to staff shortage and unless a change takes place I am sure many of The Pas Indians will take their children home. Councillor Constant took his four when he left on New Year's day. There should be no delay in appointing:

1. A Principal, who understands and is sympathetic towards children.
2. A Matron, with practical nursing experience.
3. A Laundry Matron.

Unless the above staff is supplied I know we cannot please the parents nor can we keep the school repaired and clean.

On the boy's side one toilet is broken and two others loose and leaking. All the clothes hooks are broken off the wall. The bathtubs on the boy's side are very dirty and the new ones installed a couple of years ago now look as bad as the old ones. Many of the bed springs are sprung and badly broken and should be renewed.

The Boy's Supervisor, Mr. Stone, is not well and in my opinion physically unfit to stand the work and the strain of his position. He is sincere and anxious to do well but the position demands an active healthy man.

I consider three fire extinguishers necessary—one for the furnace room, one for the engine room and one for the supply room located in the basement.

—over—

The sewing machines number six and all have been repeatedly repaired for years until now they are almost useless. I recommend that two machines be supplied.

The floors are very bad in the boy's playroom, sewing room, dormitories and in the kitchen. New floors are required - in some instances perhaps they can be covered with Battleship linoleum.

In the Grade 2 classroom the following is needed:

Grade 2 Readers (W.J., Gage & Co.)

24 Friends and Neighbours
24 More Friends and Neighbours
24 Workbook for Friends and Neighbours
24 Workbook for More Friends and Neighbours
15 ft. Good Blackboard slating

In the kitchen sufficient hot water is not available. A second hot water tank should be attached to the range - to do this we will require a water front for a McClary Chief Range and a tank. It will be necessary to engage a plumber to make the installation.

Mrs. Scott, the cook, requested that sufficient masonite be supplied to cover the work tables and also requested a new sink for the table.

Mr. Stoddart is sincere but I think cannot measure up to the responsibility or is afraid to act, fearing he has no authority. There is some clothing on hand, but he states Mr. Dixon told him it was for next fall. He also has a fair amount of jam and peanut butter etcetera but, again, appeared afraid to make any change such as to use an extra can of jam or extra lard. The dry milk purchased by the Commission has all been used yet no effort made to replace at once - the children go without. There should be supplied at least - 75 to 100 pounds of dry milk per month along with what is produced on the farm.

As I said Mr. Stoddart is doing the best he can but in my opinion this is not good enough. He was not aware that the horses and cows were all kept in one barn and that the horse barn was not in use. He failed to give me within ten of the total in residence. He was not aware that a girl attending the town High School wrote Christmas exams and, in fact, failed in some of her subjects.

I pointed out a cardboard basket full of paper and waste matter in the boy's dormitory and requested it be removed and a tin container provided. The next morning the box was still untouched. I also warned Mr. Stone of the fire hazard and he promised to carry out my request.

I do not think any school can be run long without a principal, a matron and a laundry matron. Unless these positions can be filled without delay I am afraid some of the present staff, already overworked, will leave and if this happens I fail to see how the school can be kept in operation. I consider the situation serious and the needs listed above must be met and without delay.

I probably should add, not as any threat but merely as information given to me in a statement by Chief Bignell, namely, that if there is no change in two weeks he will take his children home and so will many others. These Indians are fairly intelligent and the Chief reasonable, but I firmly believe he means business and will not hesitate to remove his children.

Attention: Mr. B. F. Neary.

I was at Elkhorn School yesterday, with Mr. Neale, of the firm of Neale, Stothard & Chapman. We found the Chief McClary heavy duty range in serious need of repair. Both fire boxes need relining and one a new water-front.

The flat rim sink, located in one end of the work table, is badly chipped, and leaks. This enamel flat rim sink should be replaced.

Three toilet bowls need to be installed. Crane's have just shipped the six complete units, which order was placed by Ottawa last April. The present water closet flush tanks are copper, and placed on the wall near the ceiling. These are past repairing, and this type cannot be replaced. The china watertanks, as you no doubt know, break very easily. I have tried to locate steel, two coat enamel, low-down tanks, hoping to make an exchange, but none are available at present. If Mr. Neale can locate, and supply the steel watertanks, may I allow him to take, in exchange, three of the china tanks now on hand? The steel enamel coated tanks may chip, but will not break, and in my opinion, are the only ones suitable for any of our schools.

You will note, the cost with board, is given as $275.00. Mr. Neale told me that this may vary slightly, due to the necessity of making changes in material, and unforeseen difficulties in repairing old, out-dated equipment. In view of the amount of money involved, I would like approval by wire.
The water front I purchased from General Steel Wares, and that will be extra. It will amount to about $50.00.

In a repair job of this nature, where the equipment is old and out-dated, it is difficult to get a definite quotation.

I would appreciate having authority to do this work, on the understanding that the total expense will not exceed $325.00, in relation to plumbing, repairing the range, and supplying additional hot water.

Yours truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I quote hereunder from a letter just received from the Acting Principal of our school at Elkhorn, Man.

"Your instructions re repairs etc. was a little late as I had already paid for the Motor and one of the grates. However, I will take the matter up with Inspector Hamilton.

The grate for the Farm Cottage is on the Beaver Lumber account. I will ask them to give me a separate account for it.

I broached the subject of repairs being paid for by the Department to Mr. Hamilton in this manner.

We require a new Automatic Control on the water pump motor. After getting a line on one with Marshall-Wells Co. at a price of $19.00 I wrote Inspector Hamilton to this effect, expecting him to order it, to which he replied:

"Small repairs of this nature are usually considered the responsibility of the School Management. If the control is needed, I suggest you order it at once, and in forwarding your voucher, send a covering letter stating the control was a necessity and urgently needed."

To date the control has not arrived though it has been ordered a week or more. From this information I gather it is not quite clear as to who should pay for small repairs, specially as far as Inspector Hamilton is concerned. The forementioned along with the Engineer's requisition, will amount to considerable and I think I should wait your advice on the matter."

I am informed by General Turner that in discussions with you it seemed clear that your Branch is prepared to accept responsibility for all essential repairs and maintenance (but not "frills") in Government-owned Schools. It appears, however, that Inspector Hamilton is under the impression that this

(over)
Administration is responsible for all minor repairs and maintenance services and, as you know, the cost of a number of minor services soon amounts to a considerable sum. I would like to suggest, therefore, that definite instructions to Agents and School Principals on this subject would be very desirable as they would clarify the situation and all parties concerned would know exactly what the Department is prepared to do regarding repairs and maintenance.

In the meantime, it will be appreciated if you would instruct your agent to look after the account for the grate for the Farmer's Cottage and the Automatic Control for the water-pump, and also if you would be good enough to reimburse us for the cost of the Motor and Grate already procured.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook

Dear Archdeacon Cock:

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, file Elk.2, we are writing to Mr. Hamilton with reference to the grate for the farmer's cottage at the Elkhorn School and the automatic control for the water pump.

You may submit for our consideration the account covering the cost of the motor and grate already secured.

To the extent that funds will permit, we are prepared to pay for essential repairs and maintenance in Government owned schools. However, we feel that when repairs are required, the principals concerned should either communicate with their agent, the inspector for the province or for that matter, they can write direct to this office, although we would prefer the application to come through either the agents' or the inspectors' office.

Many principals assume authority for repairs and several weeks later forward the account or write to the church concerned regarding the expenditures they have made. This procedure is very unsatisfactory as far as we are concerned.
We always try to deal fairly with those applying for authority for legitimate expenditures but I think you will agree that it is impossible for us to control our appropriation if principals or others incur expenditures without first receiving authority.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir;

Thanks for your letter of the 17th instant with information re the contracts awarded to Neale, Stothard and Chapman.

I would like to report that they have already installed the tank for hot water in the Kitchen and it is giving excellent results, providing ample hot water for the kitchen.

I am interested to know if there is any work planned for the Classroom building.

This building is the oldest building here, I understand, and has so many faults that it seems a pity to spend more money on it. If you were to look up Inspector Moore's report, you would get an idea of the situation. He is the Department of Education's Inspector for this District. Then again we have no Hospital in the Village now as Dr. Johnston has had to close his due to the lack of help, which means that if we have any cases of sickness that require isolation or special attention, we have no ward for them. The Junior Classroom is now in what used to be the Hospital section of this building. Hence we really need a building with four classrooms.

I would be pleased to give you any other information I can on the Matter.

Yours truly,

D.A.B. Stoddart,

Another question has been brought up in the
matter of a night watchman. Our Night Watchman
has been off sick twice lately for several days,
and last night we had to take him home about half
way through his shift, he will likely be off for
a week at least, I have already paid out $10.00
for a relief man. He is an elderly man, lives
with his wife in town, and as he only gets $40.00
a month, I feel that he should not have to pay for
the relief man. However, I do not imagine the
Administration will feel that they should either.
Would you kindly advise. Possibly he could be

job.

Re: Elkhorn School

The newly appointed Principal was expected to arrive in the near future, nevertheless, I visited the school.

It is rather difficult to describe the atmosphere of this institution - depressing would probably be the suitable word. The only bright spot was the kitchen and the staff room. The toilets were filthy and so were the dormitories. The Acting Principal can hardly be blamed as he could not make many improvements for he was expecting the Principal any day. It is rather an accumulation of many years of mismanagement than immediate negligence. I fear that the attendance will continually dwindle due to these horrible conditions. Toilet and bath facilities are inadequate. There are but four bathtubs for the girls while there are but three toilet bowls for the boys - exclusive of the one in the dormitory. I am satisfied that sanitary conditions of this school are a menace to health and are certainly not conducive to training these young people the importance of health.

Classroom Block

The classroom is built over the root cellar. It is an old building that has been repaired many times. The foundation seems to be disintegrating, the central portion having dropped several inches. The roof leaks badly; the window sills are decayed; the lighting is unsatisfactory - the windows being placed far apart and are too small.

The hot-air furnace is in the root cellar. It can readily be imagined the odour being pumped into these rooms both summer and winter.

If this school is to continue to operate a classroom block of four rooms should be built immediately, while the interior of the main building should be completely done over.

There is one classroom in the main building. This junior room appeared well organized. The permit teacher, Miss Fry, is enthusiastic and has a pleasant personality. This Indian girl would make a splendid teacher should she take training.

Repairs to the present classroom block would be a waste of money.

Definitely something should be done and done immediately, to either better the conditions of this school or close it completely.

Yours truly,

A. J. Doucet.

Dear Sir;

I regret that I missed seeing you when I was in your office last week with The Rev. Canon

A matter that is upper-most in my mind for immediate need is a small fresh-air unit, for the Principal's Residence.

The basement is so damp and unsatisfactory that food becomes contaminated soon after it is put therein. Possibly you know that if and when the sewage of the School and buildings "backsup" it does so into the basement of the said Residence. A small quantity of good food has already been wasted through warmth of weather and lack of keeping facilities. As an immediate solution; my wife is willing to put up the Cash, for a unit similar to the illustration attached, provided that you will put the purchase order through your channels for best discount. And also refund the purchase price to her in due course.

I am not certain as to whether I should address this matter to you; if such does not come under your department, will you please urge the correct person to deal specially with this item, it is urgent to health and safety, as well as conservation of food.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

Rev. W. J. J. Woods.

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

During the course of a boiler inspection at the Elkhorn Indian School, Mr. Moodie, our inspector at Brandon reports that he noted a hot water tank 8' x 44" dia. was leaking at the bottom back corner along the rivet seam. This has caused the bottom part of the shell to deteriorate.

Also, the tank and the jacket heater used for heating hot water in the tank is badly sealed. There is no means of entering this tank in order to clean the scale out or plugs in the jacket heater to provide for cleaning purposes. In view of the fact that this tank is approximately 20 years old, it is recommended that it along with the jacket heater be replaced with a new one.

For your information, there is the possibility of a plate in the jacket heater becoming overheated and if the circulation of the water were to stop, it would cause the pressure to rise in which an explosion may be the results.

I trust that you will give this matter your immediate consideration.

Yours truly,

M. Del Begio,
Chief Inspector
Mechanical & Engineering Branch.

Memorandum

Re: Elkhorn Indian Residential School,
Elkhorn, Manitoba.

With reference to Mr. Hoey's memorandum of July 14th, which bears your marginal notation of July 15th, together with attached copy of a letter from the Department of Labour, Province of Manitoba, in connection with the above, you are advised as follows.

Mr. Hoey's original memorandum under date of May 21st, 1947, with attached copy of Inspector Hamilton's letter of April 15th, 1947, did not mention any complaints in connection with the domestic hot water system at the above.

As requested by this Division, Mr. Wallace of Mr. Gow's office visited this school and submitted a complete report on the building and the heating system, and it was noted that no complaints were recorded in connection with the domestic hot water system.

For that reason, no revisions or repairs to the domestic hot water system were included in the contract for the heating revisions.

It is expected that an officer from this Division will be visiting Elkhorn on or about August 19th, for the purpose of making a final inspection of the work now nearing completion. Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Repairs to Power Line - Elkhorn, Man.

In our conversation in your office yesterday regarding availability of funds for repairs to the washrooms and coal-house at Elkhorn Indian School, you mentioned that action on these services must be deferred until you know what balance remains after necessary work has been carried out on the power line leading to the school.

It is my understanding that the maintenance of power lines leading into institutions is the responsibility of the Power Company concerned and I suggest that the repairs to the lines serving the Indian School at Elkhorn is a service that the Manitoba Power Commission should carry out at their own expense.

I suggest, therefore, that the Manitoba Power Commission be approached in an endeavour to have them do this work without charge and that the money so saved be applied toward the reconditioning of the washrooms (which are in a disreputable condition) and repairs to the coal-house (which soon will collapse if not repaired).

Yours truly,

(Henry G. Cook) Supt.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Disposal of Old Furnace as Scrap
Elkhorn Anglican Indian Residential School

You may recollect that about the middle of August last I telephoned you in connection with the disposal of the scrap resulting from the removal of the old furnace at Elkhorn and explained that it was nothing but a mass of junk with some sections broken and others so badly corroded that they are useless. Apparently your Salvage Officer had been labouring under the impression that it could be used elsewhere and for that reason I phoned you. According to my notes you said you would get in touch with the Salvage Officer and explain the situation to him and you intimated that you felt he would proceed with disposal on receipt of that explanation.

I have just been advised by the Principal that this scrap is still lying where it was last August and that he has never been given authority to dispose of it.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner

Dear Colonel Neary:

Repairs to Electric Power Line
Elkhorn Anglican Indian Residential School

In a conversation in your office on 20th August, 1948, you mentioned that certain repairs to washrooms, etc., at Elkhorn School would have to be deferred "until you knew what balance remained in your funds after the necessary work had been carried out on the power line leading into this school".

As pointed out in my letter of 27th July, 1948, this wiring is in bad condition and the lapping of bare wires has caused shorts.

I am advised by the Principal under date of 4th January, 1949, that nothing has yet been done to remedy this situation.

Will you please advise me as soon as possible what you propose to do about this wiring.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent

Dear Sir:

File: Elk-6

I am in receipt of your communication of the 16th instant regarding the notice and demand for taxes for school purposes levied by the Village of Elkhorn against the Indian School Residence situated on part K-L, Plan 76, Village of Elkhorn, and note your suggestion that we send the notice to the Dominion Government as owners of the land.

You are no doubt aware as well as we are that lands owned by the Dominion Government are exempt from Municipal taxes as such.

But you should also be aware that the occupier of such lands is liable for taxation for school purposes, and as this point of law has been established for some years in this particular case at least, I am rather surprised to have it challenged in the present instance.

Your files from the School here should show that this tax has been paid each year at Elkhorn since 1940 at least.

And further than that, the Municipal Council has not the authority to exempt such property from taxation for school purposes when occupied for any other purpose other than strictly government business.

I am sending the tax notice again to the Principal of the school here and trust that this will clear up the situation.

Yours truly  
Village of Elkhorn  

(signed) Chas. G. Webster

March 3rd, 1949.

Attached hereto please find copies of correspondence between the M.S.C.C. and the Secretary-Treasurer of the Village of Elkhorn, Manitoba, concerning notice and demand for taxes for school purposes levied by the Village of Elkhorn against the Indian School Residence, which we discussed recently by telephone.

It is understood that where officers of the Crown occupy premises on behalf of the Crown, no tax is payable.

In the present case, however, the tenant is a teacher in the employ of the Missionary Society of the Church of England and therefore, not actually an officer of the Crown.

The maintenance of the institution, however, including the salary of the teacher is in fact provided for by a Government grant voted by Parliament as part of the appropriation for Indian education. Furthermore the school is under the general supervision of this Department. In a very material sense, therefore, it is considered that the premises are occupied on behalf of the Crown.

Your advice, and if you consider it necessary an opinion from Justice on the question would be much appreciated.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

EXTRACT from a Report of the Committee of the Honourable the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency on the 30th December, 1898.

On a Report, dated 27th December, 1898, from the Minister of the Interior and Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting:

1st. That by Order in Council of the 6th October 1898, Section 35, in Township 11, Range 29 West of the 1st Meridian, was set apart for the purposes of the Indian Industrial School at Elkhorn, in the Province of Manitoba.

2nd. That the Indian Commissioner, acting in cooperation with the school authorities, has arranged with Mr. William J. Wilcox, of the village of Elkhorn, in the Province of Manitoba, to exchange the said Section 35 for lands which are considered by the said Commissioner and the School authorities to be more suitable for the purposes of the school, and which lands may be described as follows:

The South-east quarter of Section 5, in Township 12, Range 28, West of the 1st Meridian, and the South-west quarter of Section 4 of the same Township and Range, saving and excepting therefrom the four and one fifth acres of land comprised in the Canadian Pacific Railway right of way.

3rd. That the Indian Commissioner has also secured for the purposes of the school Lots Nos. 2 and 3 in Block "H", and all of Blocks "K" and "L" in the Town of Elkhorn.

The Minister considers that the arrangement made by the Indian Commissioner is in the interest of the school, and he recommends:

(a) That the action of the Indian Commissioner as to the land be approved of.

(b) That the Order in Council of the 6th of October, 1898, setting aside Section 35, as aforesaid, for the purposes of the Indian Industrial School at Elkhorn be rescinded.

(c) That authority be given for the issue in accordance with the provisions of the Dominion Lands Act of letters patent to the aforesaid William J. Wilcox for the land comprised in the said Section 35.

(d) That the lands described in paragraphs numbers (a), (b), and (c) above, and which have been conveyed to the Crown, be set aside for the purposes of the said Industrial School under Section 31 of the Dominion Lands Act.

The Committee submit the same for Your Excellency's consideration.

(Signed) J.C.

Dear Sir,

In March or April 1907 when land was being secured for the new Indian School here, a proposition was made for the exchange of the School farm and town property for other lands nearer the town and a portion of the town-site adjoining the new land, and was accepted. The School farm being considered a fair equivalent for the new lands, and the new townsite property also a fair exchange for the old lots.

The transfer as to farm lands was duly carried through and so was the townsite property so far as the Departments possession was concerned, but no equivalent has ever been given for it, as was agreed upon, and the old town lots have never been transferred in exchange, and they stand today in the name of the Supt. Gen. of Indian Affairs. The town property acquired comprised some 45 acres and was owned by one Cavanagh, he having bought from the CPR Townsite Trustees some time previously, but was still owing a balance on it. I bought out Cavanagh paying him a very substantial figure and intended paying off the balance due the Trustees, when it occurred to me that perhaps if I represented the matter properly to the Trustees and the advantage that would accrue to their property here by the location of such a building on the townsite, they might be disposed to waive any further payment. This was I am sure a perfectly legitimate transaction and a business proposition, and I enclose copies of their letters referring to it. That my suggestion was agreed to is seen by the result and I do not see why the Department has not carried out its part of the agreement ere this.

The transaction with Cavanagh has cost fully $500, and as the money was borrowed is still increasing with interest, and I am anxious to have the matter closed up and the lots sold so that I can liquidate this debt, which is pressing at present. Had I not been able to affect that transfer from the Trustees, and to get their interest free I could not have come out even on the deal as the town lots were not worth more than the 45 acre land could not have been sold then to realise the amount, but I was so anxious to have everything smoothly so that the new School would be an assured fact that a small loss would not have been considered. It is surely time now that the matter was closed up. As the other land transactions were in the name of W. J. Wilcox and it may be thought advisable to have all in one name the present transfer can be made to him also, lest there may be no further undue delay in completing this, and I enclose a description of the town lots referred to.

Yours very sincerely,

In March or April 1897 when land was being secured for the Indian School here, a proposition was made for the exchange of School farm and Town property for other lands nearer the town and portion of the townsite adjoining the new land, and was accepted. School Farm being considered a fair equivalent for the new lands, the new Townsite property also a fair exchange for the old lots. Transfer as to farm lands was duly carried through and so was Townsite property so far as the Department's possession was concerned, but no equivalent has ever been given for it, as was agreed upon, and the old town lots have never been transferred in exchange, so they stand today in the name of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs. The town property acquired comprised some 45 acres owned by one Cavanagh, he having bought from the C. P. R. Trustees some time previously, but was still owing a balance due for buying out Cavanagh, paying him a very substantial figure. I advised paying off the balance due the Trustees, when it occurred to me perhaps if I represented the matter properly to the Trustees, and the advantage that would accrue to their property here by location of such a building on the Townsite, they might be disposed to waive any further payment. This was I am sure a perfectly legitimate transaction and a business proposition, and I enclose herewith their letters referring to it. That my suggestion was not seen by the result, and I do not see why the Department did not carry out its part of the agreement are this.

OTTAWA, 29th January 1903-

In regard to your enquiry as to whether Lots 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8, Block 2, Town of Elkhorn, Manitoba, can be sold or leased and their value, I beg to submit the following report:—

On the 16th March 1891, the Department purchased from the Rev. Edward Francis Wilson the following lands for the Elkhorn Industrial School, viz.—Lots 4, 5, 6 and 7, Block 2, Lots 8, 9, 10, 11 in Block 2, Lots 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8, all in the Town of Elkhorn, according to Plan of subdivision of part of Sections 4 and 34, in Townships 12 and 11, Range 28 W 1 M., Manitoba, according to Plan by J.H. Brownlee, P.L.S., registered on the 8th November 1886, No 2939, the purchase price amounted to $1548.64, which was paid out of Parliamentary appropriation and the Deeds for the land were taken in the name of "The Honourable the Superintendent of Indian Affairs, acting for the Department of Indian Affairs."

In 1895, a fire destroyed the buildings on the above site and arrangements were entered into for the erection of new buildings on a new site, which was subsequently secured, leaving the old site as above described undispersed.

On the 14th November 1900, the Indian Commissioner at Winnipeg was requested to take such steps as he might deem necessary to dispose of the old Elkhorn school site, as the Department had no further use for the land. On the 4th December...
Indian Commissioner reported that there were no buildings on the Lots in question, which were estimated in value at between $40.00 and $50.00 each, that there was no demand for lands in Elkhorn, and advised that they be sold by auction in May or June 1901.

On a Memorandum by Mr. Benson, in the matter, of the 13th December 1900, Mr. Smart stated "Let stand in the meantime", and nothing further appears to have been done.

As the Lots above described were acquired for industrial school purposes and paid for out of the parliamentary appropriation for schools, I think there is a question as to whether this Department is in a position to dispose of the lands, unless possibly such could be done by transferring the proceeds to consolidated revenue, or whether the lands now come under the control of the Department of the Interior, as Dominion Lands, the same not being used now for school purposes.

Elkhorn.

Elkhorn, with a population of, is situated in the famous hard-wheat belt of Western Manitoba, on the main line of the Canadian Pacific Railway. It is also the terminus of the Pembina Hills Branch of the same railway. Its district is noted for the fine stands of white spruce, and crop failures are here unknown. The soil is a deep black loam with clay subsoil, and the prosperity now enjoyed by the farmers in the district is evidence of its fertility.

The district is also well adapted for mixed farming, and a large number of cattle and hogs are annually shipped. The town has two general stores, hardware, lumber yard, drug store, two blacksmith shops, two large and well equipped hotels, a chartered bank, four implement agencies, grocery store, gents' furnishing shop, two harness shops, two butcher shops, printing office which publishes a weekly newspaper, bakery and confectionery shop, two tailor shops, barber, two harness shops, two livery stables, and in fact all lines of trade are represented here. There are also three handsome churches and a large contemplated new public school. A flour mill with a capacity of one hundred and fifty barrels per day is in operation, and a elevator with a total capacity of nearly one hundred thousand bushels, together with a saddlery shop, serve the farming community. The Dominion Government has established here an Industrial School in which about one hundred children are in attendance. There is still a large quantity of virgin land within easy reach of Elkhorn which can be bought at a reasonable figure, and to secure the attention of intending settlers is directed. Parties desiring information about the town and district are invited to communicate with the Secretary of the Elkhorn Board of Trade, who will be pleased to answer any inquiries.

Your letter of the 1st inst., to hand and in reply.

With further reference to your letter of the 1st ultimo, re the purchase of the East half of Section 32, Township 11, Range 26 West. This half section has been recommended by me for purchase by the Department because they are short of land to properly carry on the work of this Indian Industrial School.

With a good farmer at the head of this department and with the number of large boys available for farm work the present area of arable land is not enough for the purposes of the school. The quarter section which is not farmed on has on it about 150 acres now broken up and as it is old cultivated land, at least fifty acres of this must be summer fallowed every year leaving only 80 acres available in each year for crop. The 160 acres on which the school buildings are situate has about twenty acres cultivated for potatoes and general farm produce. The school grounds proper consist of about sixty acres and this is light soil with solid gravel subsoil not suitable for general farming or gardening.

This leaves eighty acres for pasture and this eighty acres is badly broken up with small ponds and brush. Some of this land could be cultivated if pasture for the cattle were furnished by the new land to be bought. There is about 65 acres of broken land on the half section which will be put in crop this year, the same as last, the school paying one third of the crop as rent.

This school has now got a fine start in cattle having thirty-three head with prospects of increase to forty this year and they require a lot of land for pasture and for raising hay or green feed to keep their cattle fed during the winter months. They would have
made a fine showing on this farm last year if it had not been for a violent hail storm which struck their district on the 14th of August last. This hail storm reduced the yield at least one half. The books there show that over one hundred panes of glass were broken in the windows of the school and Principal's residence during the storm. The farmer told me that the land on this half section is of the very best quality and about 200 acres can be used for grain, the balance 120 acres, will come in very handy for pasture for the cattle. In the season of 1913 they had on this place 25 acres of wheat, 20 acres of barley and 15 acres of green feed with a yield of 462 bushels wheat, 233 bushels barley and 60 ton of green feed. Mr Waller who rents this place received in grain as rent to the value of $156.88, leaving the school double that as their share or $313.76, and this amount would have been doubled if the hail storm had not have struck them.

For some years I have been recommending certain new buildings for the Elkhorn School, new cattle barn, piggery, and cottage for the farmer, and these are required whether this land is bought or not. The only expenditure that the purchase of this farm would make necessary would be about four miles of wire fencing. I am sending you enclosed a rough pencil sketch showing the location of this half section. It lies just south of the quarter section on which the school raises all its grain. I would recommend that this half section be bought for the use of the school at a price not exceeding $25.00 per acre or in all $8000.00.

PROVISIONS OF THE ASSESSMENT ACT

Any person having an interest in any parcel of land which has been sold for taxes for more than two years may, at any time up to the expiration of six months after being served with a notice issued by the District Registrar, or at any time before issue of a certificate of title to the tax purchaser, redeem such parcel of land in which he may be interested by paying to the District Registrar the amount required to redeem as shown by the list returned to the District Registrar by the Treasurer, together with a bonus of twenty per cent, upon the whole of said amount and the cost which the applicant has been put to in proceeding to obtain a certificate of title, including his attorney's fees, if any, which cost shall be summarily fixed and taxed by the District Registrar, whose decision shall be final; upon such redemption taking place the District Registrar may proceed with the application and issue a Certificate of Title thereunder to the person redeeming or to such other person as he may find entitled thereto in the same manner as if the application had been made by the person so found entitled.

At the expiration of six months from the day of service of the last notice required to be served by or on behalf of applicant, if the land be not redeemed in the manner hereinbefore provided, the District Registrar, upon being satisfied that the purchaser has paid his purchase money in full for the land comprised in the application or any parcel thereof, shall issue a certificate of title under the Real Property Act to the applicant, for such land or parcel thereof, and such certificate of title in all respects have the same effect as, and be considered to be, a certificate of title under the Real Property Act, and thereafter no person except the tax purchaser claiming through or under him shall be deemed to be rightly entitled to the land included in such certificate of title or to any part thereof, or to any interest therein or therein, whose rights in respect thereof accrued or commenced to accrue prior to the issue of such certificate of title; and in any action brought against the District Registrar for damages under the Real Property Act by any such person claiming to have been so rightly entitled prior to the issue of such certificate of title, and who has not been served with notice under this Act, or the Real Property Act of the application for a certificate of title, it shall be incumbent upon such person to prove that the land was improperly sold for taxes, and that such tax sale as regards such land was, or should be declared to be, void.

At the expiration of six months from the day of service of the last notice required to be served by or on behalf of applicant, if the land be not redeemed in the manner hereinbefore provided, the District Registrar, upon being satisfied that the purchaser has paid his purchase money in full for the land comprised in the application or any parcel thereof, shall issue a certificate of title under the Real Property Act to the applicant, for such land or parcel thereof, and such certificate of title shall in every respect have the same effect as, and be considered to be, a certificate of title under the Real Property Act, and therefore no person except the tax purchaser, or those claiming through or under him shall be deemed to be rightly entitled to the land included in such certificate of title or to any part thereof, or to any interest therein or lien thereon, whose rights in respect thereof accrued or commenced to accrue prior to the issue of such certificate of title: and in any action brought against the District Registrar for damages under the Real Property Act by any such person claiming to have been so rightly entitled prior to the issue of such certificate of title, and who has not been served with notice under this Act, or the Real Property Act of the application for a certificate of title, it shall be incumbent upon such person to prove that the land was improperly sold for taxes, and that such tax sale as regards such land was, or should be declared to be, void.
Ottawa, September 11, 1919.

Dear Sir:

Re Additional Land for the Elkhorn School.

I have been instructed by the Indian and Eskimo Commission of our Society to bring to your notice the necessity of having an adequate amount of land for farming purposes set apart for the Indian Residential School at Elkhorn, and to request you to kindly give this matter your earliest possible consideration.

At the present time this School has approximately 320 acres attached to it, less than half of which, owing to sloughs, bluffs, ground occupied by the scattered location of buildings, etc., is capable of being brought under cultivation. As a farm of this kind and area is quite incapable of producing the amount of grain, hay, and other green feed, roots, vegetables, etc., required for the upkeep of the School, I have been instructed to recommend to you that at least an additional half section of land be secured for this purpose.

In former years when this School was operated under the direction of the Diocese of Rupert's Land, it was found necessary to rent additional land from year to year. The adoption of a similar course now, however, is one which, for many reasons does not appeal with any favour to the members of our Commission and they hope that the land required may be secured through purchase.

Mr. J.A. Macray of Winnipeg owns a half section of land which is situated close to the present School property, and being suitable from the standpoint of grazing and cultivation, might be secured for this purpose. It is known as the East
half of Section 32, Township 11, Range 28, West 1 M. Our Commission understand that the land is for sale on very reasonable terms, and would beg to recommend that steps be taken to secure it for the purpose mentioned in order that fences may be repaired or erected, and due preparation made of the fields with a view to securing a crop next year.

As Mr. Macray is at present away from the city our Commission are unable to furnish you with either the exact or even the approximate amount per acre which he would expect to receive, but they are of the opinion that $25. per acre would be a fair price.

The farm which adjoins the present School land on the West was offered for sale last year at the rate of $30. per acre if paid in cash, and at the rate of $35. an acre if paid on time. In taking these figures as a guide to the value at which owners assess their land in that district our Commission feel that the figure they have suggested would be both reasonable and just.

Commending this very important question to your early and sympathetic consideration,

I visited the Kikern Indian Residential School on the 16th of July and was much impressed by the splendid condition of the main building and the principal's residence. There has been a complete renovation and a replacement wherever necessary and these two buildings are practically as good as new. The management has commenced putting the school grounds in shape and working the farm. Dear Sir:

Your Department owns a considerable number of Lots in Blocks 2 & 3 in this Village which I believe you sold quite a number of years ago to various purchasers who made a small deposit and have probably paid nothing since.

MEMORANDUM RE LANDS AT THE ELKHORN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

In 1891, the Department purchased from the Rev. E. F. Wilson, for the purposes of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, Lots 4 to 11, in Block 2, and Lots 1 to 8, in Block 3, Plan 2939, town of Birtle. (Abstract of Title entered under 314.) The purchase price was $1,548.64. This was the site of the first school which was burned in 1895. Before rebuilding, it was decided to secure a better site.

On October 6, 1898, an Order in Council set apart Sec. 35, T. 11, R. 29, W.P., for the purposes of the Indian Industrial School at Elkhorn. This section had been relinquished by the C. P. R. for this purpose - the consideration being other lands. It was in error that this section was set aside for the Indian School. It was acquired for a trade with Mr. Wilcox, who owned land which was suitable. P.C. 2914, of December 30, 1898, rescinded the earlier O.C. and set apart, under Sec. 31, of the Dominion Lands Act.

(a) The S.W. ¼ of Sec. 4, and the S.E. ¼ of Sec. 5, T. 12, R. 28, W.P., excepting 4-1/5 a. in Sec. 4, which comprised the C. P. R. right of way.

(b) Lots 1, 2 and 3, in Block H. and all of Blocks K. & L., in the town of Birtle.

The certificates of Title for the parcels in A. and the deed for the parcels in B. were forwarded to the Interior Department with our 116823 of October 31, 1898 (Interior Dept. File 178745). The parcels mentioned in A. had been owned by W. J. Wilcox, who was given a patent, by the Interior Department, to Section 35, which had been inadvertently set apart. The town lots mentioned in B., which are the actual site of the school buildings, were a free gift from the town of Birtle or the C. P. R., or both, on account of the location of the Indian School at Birtle. These town lots were deeded on July 7, 1897, to the Federal Crown and were included when the Department of the Interior set apart lands for the school. It later developed that there had been a misunderstanding regarding the trade with Wilcox, and a Mr. Cushing, who acted for him, having pointed this out, received a special payment of $506.50 in lieu of the fact that the original town lots, which were purchased from Wilson in 1891, were not deeded to his client.

Order in Council of May 5, 1904, approved of a trade between the C. P. R. and the Department, whereby the N.W. ¼ of L.S. 14 of the N.W. ¼ of Sec. 33, T. 11, R. 28, W.P. (20 acres) was given to the Department for the purposes of the Elkhorn School, for a consideration of $150, and for 4.26 acres in the S.W. ¼ of Sec. 4, T.12, R.28, which was deeded to the C. P. R. as a gravel pit. A description of this gravel pit will be found on this file.

In 1901, it developed that the old town lots, the site of the original school, were not really required any longer. O.C. of April 23, 1906, authorized the Superintendent General to dispose of these lots. They were advertised for sale in January, 1913, and were sold by auction on April 21, 1917. The sale of Lot 1, Block 3, was cancelled and the land resumed by the Department, and on November 27th, 1924, the sale of Lots 2 to 8, Block 3, and Lots 5 to 11, Block 2, was cancelled and the land resumed by the Department. (The sale of Lot 4, Block 2,
was completed and the land patented to the purchaser in August 1921. (19675).

On October 22, 1919, the property of the Elkhorn Industrial School, excepting those lots in Blocks 2 and 3 (which the Department was trying to sell) was transferred by the Department of Indian Affairs to the Soldier Settlement Board by Order in Council. The property was as follows:

(a) The school farm, containing 311.52 acres, comprising the south east quarter of Section 5, township 12, range 28, west of the 1st meridian (160 acres); and the south west quarter of section 4 of the said township 12, range 28, 160 acres less 4.20 acres for Canadian Pacific Railway right of way through the said southwest quarter of Section 4; and less 4.28 acres for gravel pit for Canadian Pacific Railway in the north-east corner of said south-west quarter of Section 4 described in Order in Council dated the 5th day of May, 1904, (151.52 acres);

(b) Site of school buildings, containing 45.32 acres, being all of Blocks K and L (K containing 9.28 acres and L containing 32.04 acres), and Lots 1, 2 and 3 in block H (4 acres), in the town of Elkhorn; and -

(c) Hay land, containing 20 acres, being north half of legal subdivision 14 of Section 33, township 11, range 28, west of the 1st meridian.

P. C. 1165, of April 7th, 1921, returned the property mentioned in the preceding paragraph to the Department of Indian Affairs for Indian school purposes.

Approximately 378.39 acres, which may be briefly described as:

1. The S.W.¼ Sec.4, T.12, R.28, W.P., excepting 4.2 a., comprised in the C.P.R. right of way, and excepting 6.28 a., which was patented to the C.P.R. for a gravel pit, pursuant to Order in Council of May 5, 1904. This parcel contains 151.52 a. more or less.

2. The S.E.¼ of Sec.5, T.12, R.28, W.P., containing 160 acres more or less.

Parcels 1 and 2 were set apart for the Indian school by P.C. 2914, of December 30, 1898. Earlier, it had been conveyed to the Federal Crown and the Certificates of Title were forwarded to the Interior Department with our 116823 of October 31, 1898 (Interior Department File 176746). These parcels were transferred to the Soldier Settlement Board by O.C. of October 22, 1919, and returned to Indian Affairs for Indian school purposes, by P.O. 1165 of April 7, 1921.

3. Lots 1, 2 and 3 in Block H. (4 a.) and all of Blocks K. (9.28 a.) and L. (32.04 a.) in the town of EKHIWA, containing 45.32 a. more or less. This is the site of the school buildings.

This parcel was set apart for the Indian school by P.C. 2914 of December 30, 1898. Earlier, it had been deeded to the Federal Crown and deed was forwarded to the Interior Department as for parcels 1 and 2. This parcel also was transferred to the S.S.B. and, by P.C. 1165, of April 7, 1921, returned to the Department of Indian Affairs for Indian school purposes.

4. The N.½ of L.S. 14 of the N.W.¼ of Sec.33, T.11, R.28, W.P., containing 20 acres more or less. This was granted to the Department for school purposes by O.C. of May 5, 1904. The consideration was $150 plus the gravel pit of 4.28 acres in the S.W.¼ of Sec.4, T.12, R.28.

This parcel is hay land and was also transferred to the S.S.B. and then, by P.C. 1165, of April 7, 1921, returned to Indian Affairs for Indian school purposes.

5. Lots 5 to 11 in Block 2 and Lots 1 to 8 in Block 3, Plan 2339, town of EKHIWA, containing 1.55 acres more or less.

These lots were purchased in 1891 from E. F. Wilson for a consideration of $1548.64. Abstract of Title entered under No. 314. This was the site of the first school, which was burned in 1895. It may be advisable to sell these lots in the open market. An effort was made to do so from 1901 to 1917. Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re Road Survey at Elkhorn

I am advised by our Acting Principal that Government surveyors have been working on the school property, making a preliminary survey for improvements to No. 1 Highway. It is claimed that the proposed road will cut right across the school garden, within 50' of the residence.

I have taken this matter up with Inspector Hamilton who has no further information beyond the fact that a preliminary survey is being made. As the location of this school is difficult enough at the present time, in view of its proximity both to the railroad and the highway, we feel that energetic protests should be made against any change which would virtually leave it sitting on the highway. With all the open prairie to deal with it should surely be possible to carry this highway further away from the school instead of cutting across its very garden.

I trust that it may be possible to make strong representations in the proper quarter so that the interests of the school may be safeguarded in any action that is taken.

Thanking you, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Re: Elkhorn Residential School.

I have for acknowledgment your Army signal messages of April 28th and May 6th regarding the leasing of the farm lands formerly used by the Elkhorn Residential School.

The lands in question are public lands of the Dominion of Canada which by Order in Council were transferred to the former Department of Indian Affairs for the purposes of the Industrial School. Now that the School will be giving up the use of these lands on June 30th next, the question arises what use is to be made of the lands.

If the land is required for any Band of Indians we could seek authority to have the same set aside as a Reserve for such Band, but due to the location of the lands and their small area, it seems very unlikely that they would prove of much use to any group of Indians. Certainly, we could not justify setting apart the land as an Indian Reserve simply with the object of leasing it and crediting the revenue to the fund of any particular Band. However, if you had in mind establishing some Indians thereon, we would be prepared to consider any suggestion to that effect that you care to make.
If the land is not to be used for Indian Reserve purposes, then the normal course of action would be to declare the land surplus for residential school purposes and have our Minister transfer jurisdiction thereover to the Lands and Development Services Branch of this Department for such disposition as they may care to make of the same. If the land is so transferred, then it would be within the jurisdiction of the Lands and Development Services Branch to determine whether the land should be leased.

May we have a report from you regarding the establishment of the land as an Indian Reserve at an early date.

MEMORANDUM

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Elkhorn Indian Residential School

This school will cease to operate on June 30, 1949, following which both buildings and the land at present in use in connection with the operation of the school will not be required for any purpose by this Branch and should be declared surplus and transferred to the Lands and Development Services Branch for such disposal as the said Branch considers advisable. The land acquired for this school may be divided into three parts and described as follows:

(1) School Farm - area, 311.52 acres - consisting of S.E. ¼ of 5-12-28 and S.W. ¼ of 4-12-28 excepting from the latter 4.28 acres to C.P.R. for gravel pit under authority P.C. dated May 5, 1904.

(2) Site of school buildings - area, 45.32 acres - consisting of Blocks K and L and Lots 1, 2 and 3 in Block H.

(3) Hay land - area, 20 acres - N ½ of legal subdivision 14 in section 33-11-28 W.T.N.

In May, 1918, the school was closed under authority P.C. 389, dated February 18, 1918, and the land was transferred for soldiers' settlement purposes. By P.C. 1165 of April 7, 1921, it was reacquired by Indian Affairs and the school was reopened.
Information is being secured regarding the cemetery and the area which should be retained to cover the existing burial grounds and future requirements.

It is not intended to remove permanent fixtures from the buildings but all equipment used in connection with the instruction of the children will be removed for use in other Indian schools.

I am enclosing for your information a letter from Reverend Canon Cook, dated April 16, 1949, and my reply thereto of April 25th, regarding the closing of this school.

Dear Dr. Keenleyside:

It has been brought to the attention of our Department of Industry and Commerce that the Indian Residential School in Elkhorn, Manitoba, has been closed, and that the buildings housing the school are to be disposed of by your Department. At the request of residents of Elkhorn, our Department of Industry and Commerce is endeavouring to locate manufacturers who may be interested in securing the use of these buildings.

The Indian Affairs Branch in Winnipeg informs me, however, that all heating and other equipment will be removed from the building at the end of June. It would appear that the buildings would be much better suited to manufacturing purposes if the present equipment were to remain installed. The Department of Industry and Commerce would be reluctant to take any further action with respect to locating other individuals interested in using the buildings unless it had some reasonable period of time in which to work.

It is possible that the efforts of this Department may result in either the sale or rent of the premises to some interested party. For this reason it would be of considerable assistance if removal of the equipment were to be delayed for some weeks.

Should it be possible to delay action, I would be grateful if you would give some indication of the length of time which you could allow the Department in order that examination of the possible uses of the buildings and negotiations for their occupancy could be carried on. Departmental officials feel a minimum of five to six weeks would be necessary if this were possible without causing any inconvenience to your Department. I should
point out that our officials are not particularly optimistic with respect to the prospects of finding an industrial use for these particular buildings but are of the opinion that a reasonable effort should be made.

I would appreciate any comments you would care to make regarding this matter.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) D. M. Stephens

Memorandum:

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director, Lands and Development Services Branch.

Re: Elkhorn Indian Residential School.

The above mentioned school situated on public lands of the Dominion at Elkhorn, Manitoba, ceased to operate on June 30th last, and the lands and buildings are no longer required by this Branch for school purposes. In accordance with previous arrangements made between our respective branches as concerning disposal of former residential school lands, our Minister has signed an Order transferring the management, charge and direction of the said lands and buildings to your branch. I am enclosing herewith original of the said Order and a copy of P.C.1165 dated 7 April, 1921 whereby the said school lands, totalling 376.34 acres and described in Schedule "A" attached to the Minister's Order were transferred from the Soldier Settlement Board to the Department of Indian Affairs for purposes of the said school.

In the beginning, we were somewhat concerned as regards the future care of this cemetery and discussed with the Anglican Church authorities.
the possibility of the local Anglican Church taking over the care and upkeep of the cemetery, and I am enclosing herewith correspondence on the subject. It was subsequently decided that as this was not Indian Reserve land, the cemetery was not in effect an Indian burial ground, but rather an Anglican Church cemetery, and it is not considered that this Branch is responsible in any way for the perpetual care of the cemetery.

Since the closing of the school on June 30th we have had a caretaker in charge of the buildings. His employment by this Branch will cease on August 31st, and it is assumed that you will arrange to take charge of the buildings by that date.

Director.

Dear Mr. Scott,

re Indian Industrial School at Elkhorn, Man.

When I visited Elkhorn on the 4th instant, in connection with some preliminary arrangements towards the re-opening of this institution, I talked over with Mr. G.M. Shaw, who is the farmer, and with whom I was co-operating, as to the purchase of the following cattle and pigs, as enumerated in your letter, number and date as given above:

Cattle.
- 20 Cows, Holstein preferred,
- 1 Bull

Pigs.
- 1 Boar,
- 2 Sows,

I asked when he would like to have these delivered at the school. In reply he stated that he had no feed, for that reason he thought it best to defer delivery until there was a chance for them to graze. Further he named some time in July, not earlier than the middle of that month, as a suitable date for delivery. I deemed it wise to acquaint you with this fact.

This will afford time and enable the securing of good cows, a good bull can be secured much more readily, all with a clean health record.

Holstein preferred will provide a good dairy herd. In this connection I have talked with Mr. W.W. Fraser, the Provincial Livestock Commissioner, to get his views on this important matter and he expressed his opinion that good grade Short Horns might be the more suitable strain, with a well bred Bull, Short Horn. He states that they will provide sufficient milk, and if anything goes wrong, the animal can be fattened and sold to better advantage than the Holstein. This suggestion I thought it well to mention to you. The cost would be less I am informed.

I asked about the time that the farmer would like to have these delivered, and he has intimated in the fall, when he can readily provide feed for them. The farmer has specified that he would like to get "Yorkshire" strain. These can be procured locally.

your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I am enclosing herewith Voucher #2717 of Lake Winnipeg Inspectorate, which covers the cost of the 20 Cows and 1 Bull for Elkhorn School.

I have been busy securing these by careful selection for the last 10 weeks, and in doing this I was very fortunate in securing the assistance of Mr. S.G. Sims, a man of very wide and matured experience in his knowledge of cows.

I was also careful to keep closely in touch with Mr. W.W. Fraser, the Provincial Livestock Commissioner of Manitoba, another man who is an expert about this cow business.

As a result I have been able to ship a very fine car of Durham or Short Horn Cows, milk strain, and a very fine young bull, also a Short Horn.

I am satisfied that we have splendid value.

The Cows will all come shortly, one has already, the calf shown on the voucher being the result; it was a very fine calf. This means that inside of the next 3 or 4 months there will be 19 more calves added, if all goes well, and I feel that the animals will be well cared for and insure this success.

I shall be submitting a report of my recent visit, early next week, I have been busy completing this cow business since my return, the cattle all arrived safely at Elkhorn at mid-day yesterday the 26th instant.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th inst. with reference to the purchase of draft horses for Elkhorn Residential School, stating you had written to the Principal informing him that I was being authorized to purchase what I considered necessary. In your letter of the 11th March, to me, you informed me that the Department has already purchased four work horses and one driver for this Institution, and that a further request for six additional horses was made. Is there not some mistake?

Mr. Inspector Murison was sent down to the Elkhorn School last week, to enquire into the situation there, and he tells me the only horses on the place are three draft horses— one team weighing between 2800 and 3000 pounds, and another odd horse, weighing between 1600 and 1700 pounds, which is not a mate for either of the other two, and is the wrong type of horse entirely for this school, in fact there is nothing to mate him. The three horses, in his opinion, are unsuitable for an Institution of this kind, being altogether too heavy; in which opinion, I quite concur. Horses weighing about 1300 or 2600 to a team, is what was needed here; these are known as general-purpose type of horses.

If you have not made a mistake in saying five horses have already been purchased, I would only have recommended the purchase of one more horse, and sell the big horse; but I feel there is some mistake. What I would suggest, and what I propose doing, is to sell the big horse; that is if we could find anyone to buy him, which I doubt very much, and buy four more horses, making six in all. If he has six work horses and one driver, this is all they require.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I understand there is only 130 acres at present under cultivation on the school property. This, no doubt, will be increased. Six horses will be ample to work this land, because he will always have two-thirds of the land in crop, which means one-third will have to be summerfallowed every year; and all that I feel like recommending at the present time is, as I said before, six work horses. It might be necessary to buy a driver at a cost of say $60 or $70. This will not be necessary, however, if a car is to be supplied.

I am instructing Mr. Eley today to buy four horses—2 teams of horses—at a cost of about $175 a team, and to sell the big horse, if he can get a reasonable price for it. I do not know what it cost. Mr. Eley has an Instructor at the School, who ought to be a fair judge of horses, so that he can confer with him before making the purchase.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. McLean:

I beg now to submit the reply that I promised in my acknowledgement of your letter, number and date given above.

On the day I received this I also received instructions about certain shipments of materials for the addition that is being made to the Cross Lake Indian Residential School. I had to hustle these shipments to catch the first steamer of the season leaving Selkirk for the north.

I will now submit the facts about the purchase of the Cows and a Bull for Elkhorn Indian Residential School by me in October 1923.

In the letter of the 22nd March, 1923, from the Department, I was told to secure the advice of the Superintendent of the Experimental Farm at Brandon. I went to Elkhorn on or about the 4th April 1923, and my report of the 10th April, 1923 shows what I did. After I had finished the purchase of the Horses, Seed Grain, Feed Oats and Implements &c., I told Mr. G.M. Shaw, the farmer who was at Elkhorn then, that I was instructed to buy 20 Cows for the School, and 1 Bull, tyre Holstein preferred. I wanted an expression of opinion from him; he was candid and stated that he thought the Short Horn milk strain was the type that would best suit the service of the School. I noted this opinion; this animal he stated would be the best type to use for instructing Indian pupils in the care of cattle, which is an important matter in the training and educating of the Indian boys. I then returned to Winnipeg.

I may say that I was at this time endeavoring to determine what would be the best type of animal. I called on Mr. W.W. Fraser, the Provincial Livestock Commissioner, and
I told him just what I was after, he introduced me to Mr. S. G. Sims, who at the time was officially connected with Mr. W. W. Fraser, this was the first time I had met the gentleman. Mr. Fraser readily and willingly went into the whole matter with me, after talking in a general way about Cows, he told me that in his opinion that a good grade Short Horn milk strain would probably be the best and most suitable type of animal to pick out. Mr. Fraser called Mr. Sims in to the talk, Mr. Sims' desk being right alongside Mr. Fraser's. I was sitting between them. Mr. Sims was associated with Mr. Fraser in handling the Cow Scheme of the Provincial Government, and had been doing this for some years, so that he was intimately in touch with conditions relating to such business. Mr. Sims corroborated Mr. Fraser's opinion as to the type. You will note that I was talking to men of experience with reference to this Cow matter, and I feel certain that these opinions, of these men, must be respected. In our discussions, I was also particular to make clear the matter of cost, and that I wanted to get the best service for the smallest cost, which was in line with my instructions.

On the 10th April, 1923, I submitted a report about this Cow and Bull business, and I make reference to my interview with Mr. Fraser, the Provincial Livestock Commissioner. On the 25th I received a reply to my report of the 10th inst., under date the 23rd. In this reply I am told to continue my negotiations with Mr. Fraser, and in conjunction with him and Dr. Westgate, of the M.S.C.C., to make arrangements for 20 Cows that would be most suitable. This programme was followed out, I met Mr. Fraser several times. I also met the Rev'd F. Eley, who is now the Principal, at that time he was acting, and he talked with Dr. Westgate I believe, and made other inquiries, which impressed as to the qualities of the Short Horn, of the milk strain. Later I met Mr. Sims again and he reiterated his opinion about the type. I asked him about cost and he said this would run from $75.00 to $100.00 to get good cows in good condition and showing good milk conformation, and at that price I would get animals all in calf and due to freshen very soon. After this I again met Mr. Fraser, the result was that I decided that I would be wise to do business with Mr. Sims, who was now free from the Provincial Government, and in doing so I deemed it was wise to be guided by the opinion of these men who were experienced and had good judgement in this kind of business.

Then Mr. Sims picked up good cows from different farmers, in good condition and in the shape, as to calving &c., that I have mentioned above. In due course he secured the 20 cows, in about 9 or 10 weeks. He assembled them at Stowall.

At the time arranged, Mr. Fraser was good enough to come with me to examine the animals, after making a thorough examination he expressed the opinion that I had a splendid bunch.
bunch of Cows, and good value for the money to be paid for them, he also stated that this bunch was as good as he had seen for a long time, and could and would be the basis of making an A1 herd, if they were cared for and handled right, and that he had no doubt as to the service they would give, being satisfactory in every way. This opinion from such a man made me feel that I had procured the best type of animal that I could desire for Elkhorn School.

The Cows were shipped forthwith and arrived safely in due course at Elkhorn. Rev'd. F. Eley writing to me on the 27th October, 1923, makes the following statement:

"I am personally highly delighted with them (the cows) and agree with you that we have a fine herd."

With the 20 Cows I shipped a fine young Bull, Short Horn, milk strain, he has his papers, and comes of good stock. He cost $25.00, and is considered to be a fine fellow.

Since these cows arrived at Elkhorn we have added a very fine crop of calves, 19 calves are living, and 1 was born dead, from injuries in transit I understand. These calves are classed as very good, several of them being excellent I am informed. This shows that we had procured good cows of assured motherhood.

I might also state here that Mr. Sims told me that he could get me cows at from $22 to $50.00, but he said that he would not advise purchasing animals.

I have also several opinions as to the cows I bought, one from a pretty large dealer, and he told me, and he did not know what I paid, that the cows I had were worth from $70.00 to 90.00 each, and that they could not be bought for a cent less. The cows I purchased cost $85.00 on an average.

I have made inquiry as to the cost of such animals, as I got today, and I am informed that you could not get them in the same condition in every way, for less than from $65.00 to $85.

Mr. Eley, the principal, informs me that Dr. Westgate recently visited Elkhorn, that he has seen the cows and the calves, and has expressed himself to the effect that he was much pleased with the whole outfit.

The farmer at Elkhorn is a graduate of Guelph Agricultural College, and his opinion is that we have a fine bunch that are very suitable for the service of the School.

I may also state that I inquired about Holstein, but I was not encouraged about them and felt that it would be a risky and doubtful matter to get such type, and the cost was, for good stuff, a higher cost, cheap Holstein is very doubtful stuff to deal in I am informed.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Elkhorn Industrial School.

Another matter where I found an absolute waste and unwarranted expenditure was in the purchase of the milk cows for this institution. We have got 20 very ordinary shorthorns, ranging in age from four to ten years. These cows are only giving a quantity of milk today that one would expect to get from about eight cows, I think the average is about 3½ quarts per cow per day, and this quantity will reduce to about half this amount in a month's time, so you can see the position we are in regard to this matter. The cows can be replaced today for $30.00 each. Bad judgement was also shown there in the purchase of horses, and three prices were paid for them.

It is a serious matter that this mistake was made regarding the cows, because we are feeding today, 20 cows where perhaps 12 properly selected animals would supply the necessary milk that is required. The hay and feed problem here is a serious one, and I believe at the present time we have got more animals around the place than we can possibly find feed for. Dr. Westgate was up there the other day asking me to provide fencing for a small hay slough that is there. I examined the slough and there is no hay there, it is growing this wire grass which animals will not eat; they might get a couple of loads of hay off it but this would not warrant making a fence.

Long before the purchase of these cows I wrote to the Department, and also spoke to Inspector Bunn, who was instructed to deal with the whole problem, with regard to the importance of buying suitable cows for this institution in view of the fact that the number would have to be limited on account of the shortage of feed.

There has been a serious blunder made in connection with the re-establishing of this institution and it is starting out under a heavy handicap for which, in my opinion, there is no excuse.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that on Friday night last, we had the misfortune to lose one of our best cows. She had beenailing for three days and the local Veterinary Surgeon could not relieve her. A post-mortem revealed an abscess in her right lung. The Doctor is of the opinion that it was not a tubercular condition, but to make certain a smear was sent to Winnipeg for analysis and we will no doubt have the definite cause in a few days.

At present eight cows have freshened, and although our feed is of a very good quality, we are not getting a nearly sufficient quantity of milk to meet our requirements. The steer calves are being butchered as we can not afford the milk to do them justice, and the heifer calves we are endeavouring to raise in order to improve our herd. I would like your advice in this matter - shall we continue in this regard, or shall we butcher the whole which would allow considerably more for the school.

There is one four year old heifer in this herd, that had difficult parturition last year with her first calf. It resulted in a prolonged illness which naturally dried her up at once. This year she has proven sterile, and as she is consuming food feed for which we are getting no returns, are we justified in keeping her. The local Doctor has confirmed my opinion as to her sterility.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Rev. Fred Bley.

Sir:-

I beg to report that the health of your cattle is not satisfactory. Premature births and abortions have become the rule rather than the exception. This condition has materially reduced this year's crop of calves, also the flow of milk has been much lessened. You are consuming milk from diseased animals, which practice, if not actually dangerous, is certainly not to be recommended. I would also point out that your herd has not been subjected to the Tuberculin Test. This constitutes a real menace to the health of the School inmates. I may say I find the feeding arrangements and sanitation satisfactory.

I would recommend the disposal of your entire stock, and the thorough disinfection of barns as certainly the most satisfactory method of eradicating contagious abortion.

In my opinion you should be provided with a herd of straight dairy cattle, Holsteins preferred, since it is milk production you require, beef being only of minor importance.

The cost of such a change would not be prohibitive, since the present herd would bring a fair price on the public market.

Yours faithfully,
