Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

It is the Department's practice to replace milch cows at Indian residential schools when they are destroyed by order of the Veterinary General. Such destroyed animals are sometimes sold for beef. The question to be decided is whether the proceeds from the sale should be applied on the replacement of the animals or should be deposited to Casual Revenue.

I consider that the school management has some general equity in the stock at these institutions and that the proceeds could quite properly be considered school moneys. I therefore recommend that they be held to be applied on replacement costs and not forwarded to Ottawa for deposit. This would relieve the Appropriation for Indian Education somewhat.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, No. 106-0-14, saying that it has been represented that certain agricultural implements are required for the Elkhorn Indian Residential School. This is rather a surprise to me, as I am under the impression that this school is probably better equipped in the way of machinery than any school we have and the Department have been particularly generous to this institution.

You ask me to give a list of the machinery in order of importance. I may say that I cannot see that any machinery is necessary. As a matter of fact, after I received your letter I called up the Principal and asked him what was required in the way of machinery. He stated that the only thing he knew of was a plow and I am of the opinion that this is not necessary. There is less than 200 acres under cultivation at this school, which means that they should have 150 acres in crop each year. During the summer months they are called upon to summerfallow perhaps 50 acres, and this would be about 10 days work for the gang plow, which they have on hand. The Principal, when he mentioned the fact that he might want a plow, said he would not require it this year, so we have it from the Principal that he only requires a plow. Our catholic Indians and Half-breeds of Fort Alexander wish me to call your benevolent and serious attention to the following facts:

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th of January asking for certain financial assistance to the Boarding School at Fort Alexander. As you are aware this school was erected, together with the schools at Fort Frances and Sandy Bay, in lieu of the St. Boniface Industrial School, and the transfer of the property was regulated by Order-in-Council of February 8th 1904. If the Department had maintained the St. Boniface Industrial School no increased capital expenditure would have taken place; and it would seem advisable to keep the Boarding Schools upon the scale at which they were taken over.

The buildings for which assistance is requested were built before the fact of their necessity was represented to the Department and no authority was given for the expenditure. This is not the usual course and in the absence of any funds specially voted for these additions it is difficult to see how they could be allowed.

As stated in another communication, the Department has under consideration the question of per capita grants payable to schools of this class, and the claims of the Fort Alexander School will not be lost sight of.

En Mars dernier on m'a assuré que l'octroi pour les enfants de nos écoles pensionnaires sauvages avait été augmenté de $ 25.00 c'est-à-dire $ 100.00 par tête au lieu de $ 75.00. Dear Mr. Scott,

I have just returned from Fort Alexander, where I spent a week, in response to a letter from the Priest at the School, and one from the Dispenser, requesting that I go out, as there was a recurrence of the Influenza. There were about twenty-five cases when I arrived there, a good many of them were convalescing, but there were several very severe cases in the acute stage. There had been forty-five deaths since the epidemic started, on that reserve. There were no deaths while I was there, and all appeared to be getting better when I left, and no new cases had developed, so I think perhaps they have seen the last of it there.

I find that a great many of the deaths have been among the feeble and tubercular cases, and perhaps in a certain sense, it is a kind act of Providence, that they should be cleaned up.

Your obedient servant,

I have called on Mr. Ross at his office here, and I have talked over this matter with him, and I have explained to him that I had been requested to look fully into this matter as soon as possible. I also explained to him that I had, at the request of the Principal, on one occasion assembled the older boys before the whole school and the staff, and I did this to tell them that I had been informed that they were accused of being in habit of swearing. I asked the boys if they could claim that they had learned this habit in school, and they acknowledged that they had not, which statement I said must be true, as I was sure that they were taught correct conduct by everybody who was there to teach them. I also told Mr. Ross that the parents interfered about leave, so that I had to ask the principal to reduce the leave to not more than one week end per month at home. I also explained that I had seen the pupils at black-board exercises, and I was favorably impressed with their proficiency in this work, in spelling, writing and arithmetic.

I shall look further into this matter when I visit this school, I told Mr. Ross this.

Mr. Ross in turn told me that he took the action he did, so that he might be able to show this man that his complaint
was receiving attention, and that he would be able to tell this man, if he called again, that the Inspector had been in to see him, and that the matter would be fully looked into.

This man Sergius Bruyere is rather a bright man, but his energy is directed along the complaining line. I have met him, and I have told him it would be better if he would help the school by helping the staff to maintain good discipline. Dear Sir,

The Indian School of Fort Alexander, being situated in the district of the Lake Winnipeg, is altogether deprived of roads in the good season, and it can be reached only by boat, via Victoria Beach.

During the past years, we have been using an old gasoline boat, graciously placed at the disposal of the school by our Congregation; but presently that boat is out of order. Besides being unsafe, on account of its shape, it would cost too much for repairs. So now we are facing the necessity of having a new boat, or of undergoing large expenses with many unpleasant and costly delays because there is no boat service of any kind on the lake. The way by land, via Lac du Bonnet, cannot be considered on account of the distance, -60 miles,- and the absence of roads.

I have been making inquiries as to the best and cheapest way to have a serviceable boat, and I submit to your approval the following:

Sir,

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

On June 30th and July 1st I visited the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, in company with the Rev. Father Plourde of the Oblate Provincial office, St. Boniface, Man. I was impressed by the splendid site, a few miles from the mouth of the Winnipeg. The buildings were neat, but required proper fencing. The main building was well kept, but the roof and the interior of the old wing require painting. Several outbuildings also should be painted. A boat house for a 32 ft. launch is required. The barn which the Department lately erected and the implement shed erected by the principal complete the outbuildings required.

The farm is inadequate and I advised the Rev. Father Bousquet, the Principal, to make a report when the institution was prepared to do some clearing and an effort to secure more land from the reserve would be made. The garden and pasturage were very good, but field crops are inadequate.

Mechanical plant, house equipment, etc., is in good condition, with the exception of the light generating unit. I advised the principal to correspond with the Department in this connection and I see his letter is already on file. Eventually a washer and an extractor should be provided for the laundry.

I believe a mistake was made when the addition to the building was erected. There are two storeys in the addition, whereas in the main building there are three, the roof over the whole being the same level. It might be possible, without great expense, to turn the addition into a three story structure, thus providing two dormitories and a classroom below.

I purpose purchasing two sewing machines, which are urgently required, and sending authority to the agent to secure 125 ft. of rope, suitable for girls' swings.

I learned that Inspector Christianson visited the school a few weeks before I did, for the purpose of determining what painting should be undertaken. He arrived in the late evening after dark and left about 2 hours afterwards.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Graham:

Regarding the report that was brought to the attention of the Minister, the Honorable Mr. Stewart, that, at the time of my visit to Fort Alexander last summer in connection with the painting of the school, I did not arrive there until after dark, and that I requested that the children be got out of bed in order that I might see them - which request was refused by the Principal and Sisters - I might say that in looking up my daily journal I find that I visited this institution on Monday, the 9th of June, at the season when the days are about the longest.

I cannot say at just what time I arrived at Fort Alexander School, but at this time of the year it is daylight until between ten and eleven o'clock at night, and I can well remember viewing clearly the lay of the country, the situation of the buildings and the general surroundings; in fact, there was sufficient light to enable one to carry on a game of golf or any other outdoor game.

I first looked at the out-buildings, and with the Principal I measured them. We then went inside the school and viewed the downstairs rooms of the building.

Dear Doctor McGill:

The classroom work in this school is supervised by two Sisters. The grades range from 1 to 7. The junior room will accommodate 63 pupils, having 37 single seats and 13 double. The senior room accommodates 44, there being 22 double seats. At present there are about 120 pupils in residence, but a number are under school age.

The boys' dormitory is somewhat overcrowded, but this condition has been somewhat relieved by the extra small dormitory recently fitted up over the old laundry. This room accommodates 12 to 15, and has plenty of windows for the admitting of light and air. The beds in both dormitories were neatly made, and each child is provided with night clothes and a towel. The toilets and wash basins were clean and in working order.

The girls' dormitory was neat in appearance and well aired. The beds were tidy and all linen clean.

Bathrooms are provided, fitted with both tubs and shower equipment.

Hospital wards are provided for both girls and boys, but as there was no sickness, these were unoccupied at the time of my inspection. The children appeared to be

The December quarter return, which has just reached the Department, shows an enrolment of 108, or 12 less children than the number mentioned by the Inspector. Are there children in the school for whom application forms have not yet been submitted? If so, you should advise why these children are in the school without the Department's permission having been obtained.

As you are aware, grant is only provided for 90 children at this school and, owing to lack of funds, it will not be possible to provide grant for a larger number.

I would appreciate hearing from you in connection with this matter at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

Clerk-in-Charge,
Selkirk, Man.

Sir:—

I discharged seven pupils December 31st. One pupil died since. I sent four away who were not R.Catholics. I will have to discharge about seven or eight more, this present quarter, so I am about the number allowed by the Department.

The names of the pupils who would be above the number are:— Louis Johnston, 15 years, supposed to leave in June; Robert Prince, 6 years old; Louise Gagnon, 10 years old; Nora Gagnon, 7 years old; Nora Wheeler, 6 years old.

Yours truly

(Signed) M.Kalmes
Selkirk, Man. 7th February, 1933

Sir:

Replying to your letter, No. 125-1-1, of 19th ultimo referring to Inspector Hamilton's report on the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, I beg to report that on my recent visit to Fort Alexander Reserve, I visited the school but was unable to obtain any information, as Father Kalmes was absent.

On my return to Selkirk I wrote Father Kalmes and have received a reply, a copy of which is attached.

Referring to the last paragraph of his letter, giving the names of five children, I wish to point out that three of them, Louise Gagnon, Nora Gagnon, and Nora Wheeler are non-treaty. Their mothers were Indian women married to non-treaty men, and were after their marriage committed.

There are several children at present attending the school, and applications for them are ready to be forwarded to the Department. The parents of these children are destitute and the Father states it is difficult for him to turn the children away.

Your obedient servant

E. Millidge,
Acting Agent.

Dear Sir,

Reverend Father M.Kalms, Principal of the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, being at the same time in charge of a few Indian Missions, cannot easily attend to the regular administration of the School, and I believe it is in the best interest of the School to appoint a new principal. I wish to nominate Reverend Father Simeon Perrault, formerly Principal of the Fort Frances School.

If this appointment is approved, Father Perrault will take charge of the Fort Alexander School the 1st of October.

Yours devotedly,

Rev. J. Magnan, O.M.I.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively; and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pasting it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE
